**Title:** *Exegesis of the *Dao De Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Virtue) – The Hidden Chamber, Refined and Expanded, with Preface and Verse Commentaries*

**Full Title:** *Exegesis of the *Dao De Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Virtue) – The Hidden Chamber, Refined and Expanded, with Preface and Verse Commentaries.*
By **Xue Zhi Xuan** of the Yuan Dynasty. Five volumes.
This work elucidates **Chen Jingyuan’s** *Dao De Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Virtue) – *Hidden Chamber, Refined and Expanded* (*Muwu Pian*) and its preface, *Refined and Expanded Preface* (*Kaiti*).

**Foreword to the Exegesis of the *Dao De Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Virtue) – The Hidden Chamber, Refined and Expanded, with Preface and Verse Commentaries:**

The **Five Thousand Words of the Dao and Virtue** of **Laozi** have circulated in the world for **1,500 years**. Shining like the sun and moon across the heavens, it requires no praise. Commentaries—both ancient and modern—number over a hundred schools, yet despite their varying depths and breadths, all have contributed in their own way to **illuminating the sacred teachings** of the **Daoist Sage**.

I have observed **Chen Jingyuan’s** (Master Bixu) exegesis, which **weaves together the interpretations of a hundred scholars**, dissects the profound subtleties, and cites evidence with meticulous clarity. His work is **comprehensive from beginning to end**, especially prized in recent times. Yet, **beginners** who open its pages often feel **bewildered**, sighing like those who gaze upon the distant sea.

**Master Taixia Zhenren** possesses **pure virtue and refined essence**, his studies are vast and profound, and he is hailed as the **master of the feathered stream** (orthodox Daoist lineage). For **fifty years**, he has expounded the **Dao De Jing** with **deep insight**, truly ascending to the hall of mysteries. In the midst of his **refined cultivation and contemplation**, he composed **seven volumes of verse exegesis**, **two volumes of *Refined and Expanded Preface*** (*Zuanwei Kaiti*), and **two volumes of *Total Chapter Praise*** (*Zongzhang Jiasong*), meticulously **unraveling and elucidating** tens of thousands of words. His intention was to guide scholars **from the currents to the source**, seeking profundity through breadth, like climbing a ladder to reach the **ninth tier of the celestial platform**. The higher one ascends, the wider the view; thus, upon attaining the **ultimate realm of the Mysterious Dao** (*Chongxian*), comprehending the **great name of the Dao** (*Daodao qiangming*), transcending **form and substance**, and **dismissing both existence and non-existence**, one **naturally finds fulfillment beyond the mundane**, and then—**with reverence**—offers a **single pinch of incense** to **Laozi**, hoping not to betray the **earnest efforts of a lifetime**.

Though the work has long been completed, it was **kept hidden** and not published. **Master Zhang Dasheng** of **Fengxiang** and **Master Bai Xianshang** of **Meiyuan** repeatedly **urged its dissemination**, desiring to **engrave it on woodblocks** for wider circulation. **Master Liu Boying** of **Jingzhao** praised it and brought it to fruition, **entrusting me** to write this foreword. Their **noble intentions** are worthy of admiration, hence my willingness to comply.

**Li Ting’s Foreword from the *Dao De Jing* (True Classic of the Dao and Virtue) – The Hidden Chamber:**
The **unity of the Dao** permeates **all things under heaven**. It is **manifest in the Sage’s wisdom** and **expressed in the Sage’s words**.

To **observe the Sage’s words** without **investigating their origin**, one may be **confused by the myriad phenomena**—**endless, varied, and tangled**—yet unable to **grasp their totality** or **encompass their essence**. The **Dao arises from unity**, disperses into multiplicity; those who **fail to recognize that multiplicity returns to unity** have **not pursued the study of roots and origins**.

The **source of *Laozi’s* *Dao De Jing*** is **one**. Though it is called the **Upper Classic** (*Shangjing*) and the **Lower Classic** (*Xiajing*), they are **not two**; though it consists of **eighty-one chapters** and **five thousand words**, they are **not two**. Rather, **the unity of the Dao** is **embodied within** the **Upper and Lower Classics**, the **eighty-one chapters**, and the **five thousand words**, so that **all future generations** may **know the one through the one**.

The **principle of unity** is **vast and boundless**, **difficult to describe or define**. To call it **"having"**, it **cannot be spoken of**; to call it **"not having"**, it **does not depart from things**. Before **heaven and earth took form** and **all things emerged**, this was **the unity**; yet it **already existed within them**. After **heaven and earth established their positions** and **all things were classified**, this was **the unity**; yet it **was nowhere that it was not present**.

**Heaven and earth**, attaining **the unity**, became **heaven and earth**; **all things**, attaining **the unity**, became **all things**; and the **Sage**, attaining **the unity of heaven and earth and all things**, **enlightened the world**. Later generations **cannot fully grasp it through a single word or theory**. Thus, *Laozi’s* **Five Thousand Words of the Dao and Virtue** were composed.

**Master Bixu** (Chen Jingyuan) **emerged a thousand years later**, **devoted to guarding the unity** with an **empty mind**, and **inherited the profound Daoist tradition**. He **refined and expanded** the preface, and his words **reached the utmost truth**. Yet **Master Taixia Zhenren** believed that **Master Bixu’s** scholarship was **vast and profound**, his **citations broad and deep**, beyond the grasp of **ordinary students of orthodoxy**. Moreover, **after the upheavals of later times**, **scriptures were burned**, leaving **no reference for study**; he feared that **the tradition would fade with time**.

Thus, **Master Taixia Zhenren** **rooted his work in Master Bixu’s**, **cross-referenced his lifelong studies**, and **further expounded and elucidated**, composing **this verse exegesis** and **appending the *Total Chapter Praise***, totaling **tens of thousands of words**. He **dissected and organized** them, **interwove and connected** them, **explored every angle**, and **exhaustively detailed** all aspects, thereby completing this **magnum opus**. His **concerns were profound**, so his **words were precise**; his **worries were deep**, so his **explanations were thorough**. **Master Bixu’s** original work **lacked no subtlety**.

Ah, this **Classic**—**Laozi** wrote it, **Master Bixu** refined it, and **Master Taixia Zhenren** further **expounded** it. Why has it **endured through countless ages** while **so many interpretations** have been made? It is because **the principle of unity** is **difficult to describe or define**.

Yet, **future scholars** must **not fear its height** and **shrink from its difficulty**, nor **dismiss it as equal** and **treat it lightly**. They must **cultivate keen insight and clear discernment**, **progress daily and monthly**, **diligently and tirelessly** **without pause**, **deeply pondering** and **truly embodying** it, then **this unity** will **resonate within their hearts**, and **they will awaken to it without expecting to**.

Thus, **one may see** that **those who rise from the ordinary to the sacred**, **transcend the mundane**, **wander freely in the eight extremes**, and **dwell in the celestial gardens** (*Lingyuan*) may **well begin here**. Though its **remaining threads** are **coarse and unrefined**, they are **still sufficient** to **harmonize the family**, **govern the state**, and **pacify the world**.

**Master Bai Xianshang** of **Meiyuan**, **Master Liu Boying** of **Chang’an**, and **Master Zhang Dasheng** of **Fengxiang** **engraved this work on woodblocks** for dissemination, and **Master Jie Shou** of **Pucheng** (Master Jue Gong) **lectured on it publicly**. They **entrusted me** with the **foreword**, and so I **write this brief introduction** to fulfill their request.

The Great Mongol Empire, in the autumn of the year *jǐyǒu* (1299), on the seventh month’s last day, the Imperial Commissioner for the Shaanxi Waterworks, Vice-Marshal Guo Shizhong of Taihua, requested a preface.

Master Kang Jie said: *"The Primordial Diagram is the Dao of the Heart. The Heart—ah, the Heart!—is the grand repository of all principles between Heaven and Earth. The sixty-four hexagrams of the Great Ease, their pure, subtle, and profound meanings, all originate from the Heart’s designs. The teachings of the Two Sovereigns and Three Kings, their unity and adherence to the Mean, all stem from the Heart’s law. The disciples of the Mo and Si schools, their unity in loyalty and reciprocity, all derive from the study of the Heart. The profound and mysterious realm of the Spirit Palace—ancient sages delved deeply into its subtleties, probing its mysteries and hidden meanings, thereby transcending the mundane to attain sainthood, awakening to the Dao and verifying the True. Those who seek to fathom the secrets of the Primordial Diagram or penetrate the depths of the *Daode Jing* must, above all, enter through the One Heart.*

*Across countless ages, the transmission of the Heart to the Heart, of the Sage to the Sage, has revealed Laozi’s unspeakable teachings and uncovered the hidden mechanisms of the Primordial. Only the True Person of Great Xia was capable of attaining this.*

*When he refined his eloquence in the gardens of letters and led the Confucian scholars, his prestige was unmatched. Later, as he explored the Dao’s threshold and delved into its mysteries, his teachings became the standard by which the sect was measured. Favored by two dynasties, his fame endured through the ages. Once dwelling in the sacred Hua Mountains, he gathered disciples and friends, gazing down upon the world’s dust, truly embodying the authentic and the practiced for many years. In the winter of *dīngwèi* (1307), Marshal Wang Pingdong, the Conqueror of Cold, extended an invitation with great ceremony. The True Person, though far, graciously accepted, arriving on a crane’s reins and a crane’s steed, making Kangtong his permanent abode—truly the rebirth of Guangchengzi.*

*The mountains and rivers took on a new splendor, the grasses and trees grew brighter, and the air was filled with harmonious qi, while the teachings resonated like a swelling tide. Those who heard the echoes and glimpsed the radiance were not merely the tens of states of Shaanxi. For when even an inch of land is illuminated, the boundless sky is unobstructed; when the Spirit Platform is clarified, still waters mirror the heavens. Like the moon after rain, the breeze after calm, a chest of wine poured freely, the ice wheel and jade mirror—his mind was open and luminous. With the learning of self-attainment through the One Heart, he expounded the effortless essence of the Two Classics, elucidating their themes and citing their texts. The profound meanings became clear, the doctrines were meticulously explained, ancient and modern verified, doubts dispelled—each word a gateway to the mysterious, each character a manifestation of eternal truth. The open are easily enlightened, the enlightened easily attain. Laozi’s original intent shone like the sun, and within the mysterious, there was awakening, beyond doubt. Those who read it were invigorated in body and mind, merging with the text—entitled *Exegesis of the True Dao Classic*.*

*Young scholars, like those emerging from clouds to see the blue sky, ascending Kunlun to find a piece of jade, are fortunate indeed to benefit from this. Is this not magnificent?*

*One day, Marshal Wang gathered the scholars in court and instructed his attendant: ‘The True Person’s *Exegesis of the True Dao Classic* shares the same Heart-law as Laozi himself—truly something unseen by later learners. Among the Dao companions, Master Zhang of Xiqian has already had it engraved on woodblocks. Yet fearing its transmission was not yet widespread, he wished to have it inscribed with lacquered court seals and stored on fine paper, printed and disseminated broadly to expand its reach, serving as the key to unlock the gates for scholars. This is indeed a great kindness.’*

*The attendant replied: ‘The pearl of the Jin and the jade of Zhao—why seek a merchant?’ I, unworthy as I am, how could I comprehend the Sage’s intent? I declined, but my refusal was not accepted.*

The presumptuous praise I dare to append is like imitating Heaven and Earth or painting the sun and moon—one only reveals their ignorance of measure.

To obtain the fish and forget the basket, to obtain the hare and forget the snares, to obtain the elephant and forget the words—this belongs to those later Dao cultivators who attain it themselves.

At the time of the *ji-you* year without a *wu-she* day (645 CE), I, the Old Man of Great Dawn, resided in Pingzhou, where the scholar-official Feng Fuxu recounted the *Collected Micro-Commentaries on the Hidden Meanings of the Dao/Way and Virtue Classic*, Volume One of the *Exposition of the Opening Themes*.

The True Person of Azure Void said:

The two Classics of *Dao/Way* and *Virtue* by Laozi encompass a comprehensive discourse on emptiness, void, and nothingness; natural virtue and power; divine harmony and great unity; Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang; the sages, feudal lords, and commoners of all ranks; and the movements of plants and animals. They are vast yet contain nothing they do not embrace, subtle yet encompass nothing they do not permeate.

Thus, Sima Qian praised them, saying: *"The Nine Classics are vast, yet none surpass the brevity of these two chapters."*

Now, as I expound upon this Classic, I first clarify the sovereign intent behind its transmission, then reveal the author of this commentary. This Classic is spoken by the Most High Lord Laozi, the *Collected Micro-Commentaries* are composed by the True Person of Azure Void, Chen Jingyuan, and the *Opening Themes* are his own account. Though unworthy, I, the Old Man of Great Dawn, dare to expound upon the thematic outlines and elucidate the *Opening Themes*, hoping scholars may discern the origin and purpose of the Primordial One’s transmission, understand the True Person’s exposition of the Primordial Way, and enter through these thematic outlines.

To measure the sea with a ladle, to gaze at Heaven through a tube—this is truly the ignorance of measure.

Now, I shall open the themes, dividing them into twenty categories, listed as follows:

1. Clarifying the True Person of Azure Void’s original intent in compiling the *Collected Micro-Commentaries* and *Opening Themes*.
2. Correctly interpreting the *Opening Themes*, first elucidating the Most High’s surname, given name, and honorific titles, then explaining whether he is the Sovereign of Ten Thousand Heavens or the Teacher of a Hundred Kings, revealing his hidden and manifest traces.
3. Clarifying the era, month, day, and hour of the Most High’s conception, gestation, and birth.
4. Clarifying the Most High’s divine appearance after birth, his seventy-two auspicious marks, eighty-one virtues, and the region where he resided.
5. Clarifying how the Most High, though a hidden sage, lived as an ordinary mortal, serving in lowly ranks to assist the rulers of his time, and his departure from the Zhou dynasty.
6. Clarifying the biography of the True Person of the Pass and his divination of stars and qi, recognizing the omen of a sage crossing the Pass.
7. Clarifying the year and month of the Most High’s crossing of the Pass, and his subsequent meeting with the True Person Yin in the market of Qingyang, Shu.
8. Clarifying how, during the reign of King You of Zhou, the Most High returned to Central China. *The Broad Exegesis of the Sacred* states that he returned during the reign of King Ping, allowing Confucius to inquire about rites and lament that he was like a hidden dragon.
9. Clarifying how, knowing the Zhou Way was declining, the Most High crossed the Pass again, changed his name and titles, concealed his extraordinary abilities, and lived as a commoner, with his lifespan unknown to all.
10. Clarifying how the Most High, embracing the Dao and virtue, lived as a hidden sage among mortals, with his lineage enduring through generations, his descendants never ceasing their sacrifices.
11. Clarifying how the Most High is the spirit of one who attains the Dao, receiving the title Laozi.
12. Clarifying how the Most High possesses divine powers, acting as the sovereign of the Dao, transmitting teachings to the world through myriad methods to save humanity.
13. Clarifying how the Most High, through serene inaction and non-doing, preserved this within, and through harmonizing with the mundane, responded externally, thus earning the title *True Person of Great Assistance*.
14. Clarifying how Laozi and Zhuangzi also had wives and descendants, yet as masters of the Great Dao, they wished later generations to know that the Way of longevity could be attained through diligent cultivation, not through supernatural means alone.
15. Clarifying how the Most High’s profound benevolence pervades all, his sacred virtue enduring far and wide, with each dynasty venerating him, his temples and statues never vanishing, hence the Tang’s honorific title of *Holy Ancestor*.
16. Clarifying why later recipients of these two chapters titled them *Classic*.
17. Correctly elucidating the meaning of *Dao/Way and Virtue*.
18. Correctly interpreting the Classic’s teachings and the intent behind the eighty-one chapters of the two Classics.
19. Clarifying the fundamental principles of the two Classics of *Dao/Way and Virtue*, their essence for governing the state and cultivating the self.
20. Clarifying why the True Person of Azure Void compiled and expounded upon these commentaries, unfolding the meaning of *Dao/Way and Virtue* for the benefit of later scholars.

The commentary states: This first category clarifies the True Person of Azure Void’s original intent in compiling the *Collected Micro-Commentaries* and *Opening Themes*.

Now, as I expound upon this Classic, I first elucidate the *Opening Themes*. Having interpreted the *Opening Themes*, I must then clarify the author who first composed them.

These *Collected Micro-Commentaries* and *Opening Themes* are the work of the True Person of Azure Void, Chen Jingyuan, with the given name Jingyuan, courtesy name Taichu, and mystical appellation Azure Void Child. His family hailed from Jianchang.

His great-grandfather, Zhixun, and grandfather, Lingxin, both gained renown for filial piety in serving their parents, both refusing high office.

The True Person’s father, the late Prefect, was elevated to the rank of *jinshi* (advanced scholar), and his surname was **Xu** (解胊, *jiě tuó*), with the given name **Yu** (玉, *yù*).

The late Prefect served as a County Magistrate in **Shan County** (山令), residing in **Gaoyou** (高邮), where he passed away due to illness. His mother, the late Lady, lived in poverty without means to return home.

They had four sons, with the True Person being the youngest. When his elder brothers died in succession after the **Chuxiao** (除祥) event, he alone remained with a resolve to pursue the **Way of the Outer World** (方外志).

In the year **Regong 2** (庆历二年), he took **Master Han Zhizhi** (韩知止), the **Ritual Master of Tianqing Observatory** (天庆观礼崇道大师) in Gaoyou, as his teacher. In the third year, he passed the **examination of Daoist scriptures** (经度) and became a **Daoist** (道士). At eighteen, he set out on his travels, visiting famous mountains, and reached **Tiantai** (天台), where he studied the *Sutras of the Three Caverns* (三洞经). There, he encountered the **High Daoist Zhang Wumeng** (张无梦), and from him, he gained the subtle **Dao/Way of the ancient Laozi and Zhuangzi** (老庄微旨).

Later, he secluded himself in the **Jiang-Huai region** (江淮间), finding amusement in **Daoist music and texts** (琴书).

After some time, he wished to visit the **capital** (京辇), and **Yang Shijun** (杨使君), the **Secretary of the Ministry of Rites** (礼部侍郎) **Wang Qi** (王琪), recommended him in verse to **Wang Xigong** (王岐公):

*"The old words of the Ao Mountain are long,
And I delight to see the square pupil again."*

At that time, **Xigong** served as **Hanhua Academy’s Chief Editor** (翰林承旨), and he was pleased by his arrival. Thus, he was enrolled in the **Ruiyun Daoist Monastery** (瑞云), and repeatedly requested him to lecture on the *Two Daoist Classics* (道德二篇) and the *Southern Flower Sutra* (南华). His lectures never ceased.

At that time, **high-ranking officials and scholars** (公卿大夫) all sought to recognize him.

Then, the **Liquan Daoist Monastery** (醴泉观) promoted him to **Chief Compiler** (提总奏) and assigned him to the **original observatory** (本观) as its **Editor** (修撰). When he visited **That King’s Temple** (那王谒真君祠), he was summoned to discuss **Daoist matters** (道家事), and his **comprehensive response** (该通) earned him the **Purple Robe** (紫衣).

Emperor **Shenzong** (神宗) established the **Grand Universal Daoist Ritual** (普天大醮), and he was ordered to draft the **Sacred Daoist Texts** (劲令修撰青词). His work was well-received, and he was further instructed to participate in the **construction of the Jianchang Pavilion** (建章阁) alongside **Tianjie** (天节) in the **ritual offerings** (修奉). Following this, he was granted an audience and bestowed with the **appellation of True and Tranquil** (真靖之号).

In the fifth year of **Xining** (熙宁五年), he submitted his annotated *Dao/Way and Virtue Classic* (所注《道德经》). The imperial decree praised it:

*"The Classic submitted by Chen Jingyuan dissects the profound, analyzes the subtle, synthesizes the teachings of a hundred schools, and its meaning is detailed and complete—truly worthy of adoption. Among his peers, he should be commended and rewarded. Thus, he is specially appointed as the **Right Street Chief Supervisor** (右街都监), overseeing the **signing and dispatching of Daoist teachings** (签书教门公事). His honor in the Daoist ranks was rare at that time."*

The Emperor summoned him back to Gaoyou to attend to his parents’ burial. At that time, the court dispatched an imperial envoy bearing a gift of thirty *jin* of white gold, and further proclaimed:

*"Now that the Taiyi Palace has been completed within the capital, let Chen Jingyuan oversee it."*

Upon his return to the court, he was ordered to select and ordain disciples of strict discipline and purity—no more than twenty in number—to assist in the rituals. On the twelfth day of the eleventh month of the sixth year of **Xining** (熙宁六年), he was summoned to the **Yanhe Hall** (延和殿) for an audience, where each was granted official ranks and responsibilities.

On the fifteenth day, the **Taiyi Palace** was consecrated. On the following day, the imperial procession visited the palace, where the customary rites were completed. In the **Yanqi Hall** (延棋殿), he was granted a special promotion to **External Right Street Vice Daoist Master of Records** (额外右街副道录), and three of his disciples were ordained. Additionally, the palace was permitted to ordain one disciple annually, with monthly provisions of sixty *hu* of rice for offerings, twenty thousand strings of cash, and grants of land in the southern and northern estates to support the community.

After some time, due to the burden of his duties, he requested leave and retired to his secluded hermitage at **Fufu**. The local officials reported this to the court, but the request was denied.

A further imperial decree was issued, entrusting him with his original official duties and ordering the palace clerks not to interfere. Each year, the number of ordination certificates was increased by two. Later, due to discrepancies in the **Nine Ranks of Ritual Offerings** (九等斋科), and the lack of proper hierarchy in the imperial Daoist titles, the court established an office and selected three Daoist masters to examine and rectify these matters, so that the **Zhenren** (真人) could oversee their assessment.

The Right Censor-in-Chief **Li Suzhi** (李肃之), the **Gunmi Direct Scholar** **Sun Yong** (孙永), and the **Promoted Discussant** **Yang Jie** (杨杰) were appointed to oversee the editing and polishing of the texts. Upon completion, they were presented to the throne, and he was granted silk banners, ordination certificates, and the title of **Purple-Clad Master** (紫衣师号), along with permission to promulgate the revised texts.

At that time, the court sought to bestow the titles of **Nine-Heaven Exploring Envoy** (九天探访使) and **Five-Peak Venerable Master** (五岳丈人). The Grand Chancellor petitioned that the **Zhenren** be granted official robes, insignia, and titles. Thus, the **Zhenren** drafted the formal protocols, and the titles were conferred: **Yingyuan Baoyun Zhenjun** (应元保运真君) for the Nine-Heaven Exploring Envoy and **Chufu Dingming Zhenjun** (储福定命真君) for the Five-Peak Venerable Master. Among his hidden works was the *Xuanri Zhongyu* (轩日种玉).

From the Grand Chancellor **Wu Kui** (吴奎), the Left Chancellor **Pu Zongmeng** (蒲宗孟), and the **Hanlin Scholar** **Wang Qi Gong** (王岐公) down to the eminent artisans, scholars, and virtuous officials of the time, many composed poems in mutual exchange and presented them to him. Due to their abundance, they are not fully recorded here but are included in his separate biography.

In the capital, there were twelve Daoist officials, who, in the reigns of the ancestors, oversaw the official observatories within and without the imperial city, presiding over the rituals of incense-offerings and sacrifices. Those who demonstrated diligence were appointed to public office upon imperial decree. Whenever there were vacancies, they petitioned to be tested on the *Daode Jing*, the *Nanhua Jing* (《南华经》), and the *Lingbao Duren Jing* (《灵宝度人经》), along with the ten doctrines of Daoist practice.

The Emperor approved their request and ordered the Bureau of Compilations to oversee the examinations. Thereafter, Daoist learning underwent a profound transformation, marking a new beginning from that point.

In the sixth year of Yuanfong (元丰六年), the affairs of these Daoist observatories were abolished, and he retired into seclusion at Mount Mao (茅山), where he collated and corrected the scriptures of the Three Caverns (三洞经法). Seekers of the Dao from all quarters flocked to him, their numbers swelling.

After some time, he donned the simple attire of a scholar-official, carrying a satchel, and traveled to Mount Song and Mount Tai to seek out places for alchemical refining. In the third year of Yuanyou (元佑三年), while passing through the capital, he was invited by the officials of the Middle Taiyi Palace (中太乙宫) and below to oversee its establishment. The Daoist Master had played a pivotal role in its founding, so they urged him to stay, offering him the reverent offerings of *zhīmù* (芝木). Shortly afterward, the court reinstated him to his former position as Right Street Daoist Registrar (右街道录).

The Right Vice Chancellor, Su Shi (苏轼), said to him: *"The Venerable Master should transmit his teachings to his disciples; otherwise, the art of refining may not endure for future generations."* Among his vast collection of over a thousand volumes—both inner and outer texts—were all those he had personally annotated. He also meticulously copied out three hundred scrolls, mastering the fine cursive script, and his calligraphy closely followed the styles of Ouyang Xun (欧阳询) and Chu Suiliang (褚遂良). His written works included:
- *Cangshi Zuanwei* (《藏室纂微》), two volumes;
- *Nanhua Jing Zhangju* (《南华经章句》), seven volumes;
- *Zongzhang* (《总章》), three volumes;
- *Chaoyi* (《抄义》), three volumes;
- *Baozhu Miaoyi* (《宝珠妙义》), three volumes;
- *Fujie* (《肤解》), one volume;
- *Yizhen Jianhou Yi* (《翼真检后义》), one volume;
- *Xugao Shi Zuan* (《续高士篡改为《退身传集》》);
- Three commentaries on the *Tongxuan Jing* (《通玄经》);
- Four commentaries on the *Duren Jing* (《度人经》);
- Exegeses and annotations on the *Xisheng Jing* (《西升经》).

In his later years, he devoted himself entirely to alchemical practice, purchasing cinnabar from Gengling (绛陵), refining it in his sacred chamber, and distilling the elixir, striving for the ultimate attainment of the Nine Returns and Seven Rebirths. His lifespan neared its limit, yet he remained vigorous. He often consumed mica powder and claimed that in his youth, he had ingested cinnabar, retaining the vigor of youth despite his silvered hair—his complexion and flesh remained as youthful as ever.

In the fifth month of the first year of Shaosheng (绍圣元年), without any prior illness, he suddenly lost his appetite, drinking only water thereafter. By the thirteenth day of the sixth month, at noon, he requested a bath and new robes, then summoned his disciples to gather before him. He said: *"Write my death notice: ‘Departed to the Primordial Child’s Palace of the Three Pure Ones.’"*

After they had written it, he had them placed outside the hall of abstinence and ordered his body to be cremated. He then arranged his sitting cushions facing the northwest and, after refining his body and gazing toward the Celestial Gate, softly tapped his teeth, then sat again. He instructed his attendants to prepare a stack of bamboo slips and wrote a farewell inscription to show the disciples, declaring:

*"Once I was in harmony with the Dao,
Now I shed this mortal form.
Neither transformation nor birth—
I return to my true abode."*

As he finished speaking, his vital essence ascended with a prolonged sigh, and he departed in tranquility. His body was temporarily placed at the Yangsheng Yuan (养生院) outside the Xuanhua Gate (宣化门).

From the moment of his physical departure until the time of his spiritual ascension, the height of summer had arrived, yet his form remained serene and lifelike. All who gazed upon him—regardless of age or station—unanimously marveled and sighed in reverence.

The sage enjoyed the blessings of spring and autumn for seven decades,
And as he reached mid-autumn, his life’s light extinguished—
His mortal form was laid to rest in the burial ground granted by his ancestral temple.

At the moment the grave was sealed,
Suddenly three *jiaxié* butterflies fluttered and danced before it,
And after a time, the grave was leveled—
They then drifted away toward the southeast.

The *Jixian* Palace scholar and compiler Wang [□] inscribed an epitaph, saying:
*"Ah! There was the sitting-forgetfulness of Sima Xi of the Tang,
The eloquent writings of Wu Zhengjie,
And the teachings of Du Guangting.
Though these three masters excelled in different eras,
Our sage encompassed all their virtues.
Thus, his disciples praised him so."*

Though he mingled with court officials and scholars of the realm,
He never bowed in deference to any—
Yet in his studies, he was never weary, even in old age.
Thus, he delved into the *Lánghán* treasures and *Bǎojí* classics,
The *Jīnjiān* and *Yùshū* of refined insight,
Seeking the profound mysteries of the Dao.

When it came to expounding teachings in gatherings or private discourse,
His brilliance and persuasive argumentation were unmatched.
Those who questioned the *Lǎozǐ* or *Zhuāngzǐ* of old times
Found their doubts clarified by his elucidation of the essential truths.

In all his poetic works and miscellaneous writings,
He mastered the styles of *Táo Yī* and *Gě Yǐ*,
So his phrases were bold yet refined, vigorous yet elegant—
Ministers and officials alike sighed in admiration.

His *Qíjiè* departed, ascending to the void and entering stillness,
Beyond mortal measure.
Yet they imagined his divine form,
And together sought to preserve his teachings of virtue.

For the conduct of a true person,
Its beginning and end were briefly mentioned before.
The meaning of *kāití* is now clarified in the following passage—
The text will dissolve its enigma.

For *kāi* is to unfold,
And *tí* is to mark a title.
It means to unfold this *Sūtra*’s principles
And mark its themes,
So as to reveal them to future generations.
Thus it is said *kāití*,
Or also *kāishì* this *Sūtra*’s title.

Before expounding the text,
One must first interpret its title.

This *Sūtra*’s title is called:
*The Tàishàng Dàodé Jīng Cángshì Zuǎnwēi Kāití*.
*"Tàishàng"* is the honorific name of *Lǎojūn*.
*"Dàodé"* is the foundation of the Five *Cáng* Virtues,
And the source of all *Fǎ*.
*"Jīng"* means eternal principle,
*"Fǎ"* means eternal law.
It states that this *Dàodé* is the unchanging law for all ages.
*"Cáng"* is pronounced with level tone—
Also..."

*The Chamber of Secrets*

*"Shì"* means **the innermost sanctum**.
It refers to the **hidden chamber of the *Xuāndū* treasure trove**—
the **perfectly concealed scriptures**.

*"Zuǎn"* means **to gather and compile**.
*"Wēi"* means **profound subtlety**.
It refers to **delving into the arcane texts of the hidden chamber**,
**compiling the subtle intentions of past sages**,
so as to **verify and elucidate the *Dàodé***.
Thus it is said:
*The Tàishàng Dàodé Jīng Cángshì Zuǎnwēi Kāití*.

This is its **general outline**.

As for the **detailed interpretations following the text**,
they are already **exhaustively explained in the *Kāití* section by section**.
Now, this *kēwén shū* is merely **the *Tàixiá Lǎorén*’s misguided exposition of the *Kāití*, leading to confusion**.

*"Shū"* (平音) means **to clarify**.
*"Jué"* means **to resolve**.
It is like **stagnant water blocked and unflowing**—
**clearing its channels in sequence** so that it **pours into the rivers and seas**.

Now, I shall **divide the *Kāití*’s main framework into twelve categories**,

**Exposition by the *Tàixiá Lǎorén* Xué Zhìxuān**
**Opening the Title**

The **Title** states: *"All titles called 'Kāití' are indeed the opening exposition of the *Bìxū*."*

The *Lǎozǐ* bears the surname **Li**, given name **Ēr**, with the courtesy name **Pìn**, or alternatively **Bóyáng**. According to the Daoist scriptures, he **emerged before the void’s formation**, mastering the subtleties of natural transformation, and **dwelled perpetually in the heavens**, serving as the sovereign teacher of the emperors. This pertains to matters beyond the six directions, thus omitted here. Only the broad outline is presented, excluding divergent accounts.

The **Exposition** states: This is the **second category**, properly elucidating the *Kāití*, first clarifying the *Tàishàng*’s surname, given name, courtesy name, and posthumous title, then revealing his dual roles—as sovereign of the ten thousand heavens and teacher of the hundred kings—manifesting in hidden and revealed forms. Within this category, it is further divided into two sections:

The **first section** clarifies the *Tàishàng*’s surname, given name, courtesy name, and posthumous title.
The **second section** clarifies how the *Tàishàng* serves as sovereign of the ten thousand heavens and teacher of the hundred kings, embodying hidden and revealed traces.

As for the **first section on the surname, given name, courtesy name, and posthumous title**, the *Title* states: *"The Lǎozǐ bears the surname Li, given name Ēr, courtesy name Pìn, or alternatively Bóyáng. Some say his posthumous title is Zhí."* The name *Lǎozǐ* is the *Tàishàng*’s inner designation, already detailed in the **eleventh category’s exposition**. The surname *Li* and its origin are elaborated in the **third category**. Now, the derivation of his taboo name, courtesy names, and posthumous title shall be sequentially explained.

His **taboo name** is *Ēr*, his **courtesy name** is *Pìn*, or alternatively *Bóyáng*, or his posthumous title is *Lǎo Pìn*.
As for human life, one has a **name**, a **courtesy name**, and a **posthumous title**; upon death, one receives a **posthumous title**. Some posthumous titles are conferred based on virtue, others symbolizing form. The *Lǎozǐ*’s ears were large and drooping—hence the posthumous title *Lǎo Pìn*. The *Lǎozǐ* was born with large ears, and three **leakages** (*sǎn lòu*), their appearance shameful and pendulous, marking the **distinctive mark of a great sage**. Thus, later generations posthumously titled him *Lǎo Pìn*, grounding the *Tàishàng*’s name, courtesy name, and posthumous title.

As for the **second section on the sovereign of the ten thousand heavens and teacher of the hundred kings**, the *Title* states: *"According to Daoist scriptures, he emerged before the void’s formation, mastering the subtleties of natural transformation, and dwelled perpetually in the heavens, serving as the sovereign teacher of the emperors."* The **Daoist scriptures** refer to works such as the *Xuándū Bǎozàng*, *Sāndòng Sìfǔ*, and *Lóngzhāng Fèngzhuàn*—collectively termed *scriptures*. Within, it is said: *"The *Tàishàng* emerged before the void’s formation, mastering the subtleties of natural transformation."* The term *stubbornly emerging* (*tǐng*) signifies surpassing all things in vitality and prominence. *Space* (*kōng*) means *emptiness*; *void* (*dòng*) means *permeation* and *nothingness*. Before the chaos of *Húntún*, in the silent interplay of *having* and *not-having*, only the boundless void pervaded naturally. According to the *Guǎng Shèngyì*: *"The *Lǎojūn* originated from the beginningless, arising from no cause, as the first of all *Dao*s and the ancestor of *yuánqì*. At that time, there was no light, no form, no color, no sound, no origin, no thread—dim and obscure, hence called *space-void*."* It further states: *"The *Lǎojūn*’s essence is *emptiness*, his nature *spontaneity*. Nothing could make him thus, nor could anything prevent it; he did not know why it was so, nor why it was not—hence *spontaneity*."* It speaks of the *Tàishàng Lǎojūn* having no supreme ancestor, his body being the *Dao* itself—condensing into form, dispersing as *qi*, embodying the subtleties of spontaneity, wielding authority over creation. Before the chaos had yet divided, in the space-void’s uppermost expanse, his *Dao*-body already distinctly emerged, manifesting at that time. The scripture states: *"I know not whose child I am, preceding the August Sovereign"*—this is the meaning.

As for **dwelling perpetually in the heavens**, it refers to his sojourn through the various heavens, serving as the teaching sovereign of the ten thousand heavens. According to the *Yóulóng Zhuàn*: *"In antiquity, Yín Zhēnzhēn followed the *Lǎojūn* westward into the flowing sands, and upon returning, ascended with the sacred retinue to traverse the three realms and nine heavens, reaching the ten thousand heavens."* Each time the *Tàishàng* arrived at a heaven, he saw its imperial sovereigns, golden boys and jade girls, ten thousand chariots and a hundred thousand cavalry, jade banners and feathered canopies, celestial music filling the sky as they came to welcome him. Within that heaven, the *Tàishàng Lǎojūn* toured its palaces, expounding profound *dharma* to its inhabitants, serving as their teaching sovereign. Likewise, in every other heaven he visited, the ceremonies, music, feasts, palaces, and scriptural transmissions followed the same pattern, extending universally across the ten thousand heavens.

According to the *Guǎng Shèngyì*: *"The *Lǎojūn* also ascended to pay homage to *Yuánshǐ*, leveling his voice. He reported on sins and blessings, attended the *Yùchén* audience, recorded the nine palaces, and oversaw the registers of life and death across the three realms. Before him stood countless heavenly kings, seeking guidance on wind, rain, drought, famine, prosperity, adversity, life, death, virtue, and vice."* Thus, traversing the ten thousand heavens, he propagated the *Dao*’s transformations, ever-present in the *Tàichì* Palace of the *Tàichìng* Realm within the *Tàixiāng* Heaven. Hence, it is said he **dwelled perpetually in the heavens**.

As for **serving as the sovereign teacher of the emperors**, the *Guǎng Shèngyì* states: *"During the era of the Three Sovereigns, humanity remained pure and unadorned."*

In the **Honglong** year of the **Dragon Han** era, he was titled *Xuánzhōng Dàfǎshī*, and with the *Shàngqīng Shèngjiào*—twelve volumes—he propagated the **Great Vehicle Dao** to enlighten both heaven and humanity.

During the **Middle Three Sovereigns**, in the **Chiming** year of the **Red Bright** era, he was called *Yǒugǔ Xiānsheng*, and he revealed the *Língbǎo Zhēnjīng*—twelve volumes—expounding the **Middle Vehicle Law** to awaken all beings and rescue the myriad people.

In the **Lower Three Sovereigns** era, as human hearts grew scattered and crude, he descended in the **Kaihuang** year, taking the title *Jīnquè Dìjūn*, and revealed the *Dòngshén Zhēnjīng*—twelve volumes—propagating the **Lesser Vehicle Law** to enlighten all ranks of beings.

These thirty-six volumes of scriptures left behind during the **Upper, Middle, and Lower Three Sovereigns** eras were kept secret in the heavens and not transmitted to the world.

According to the *Xuángāo Lùn·Shéndào Shèjiào Zhāng*: *"Initially, the Dao was concealed in the Upper Mysteries; its final dissemination reached the Lower Earth."*

Later, in the time of **Fuxi**, humanity had become licentious and undisciplined, lacking laws and rites. The *Lǎojūn* then, in the **Qingzhuo** year, assumed the title *Yùhuáchīzi*, descending as a teacher to instruct him in the *Yuányáng Jīng*, teaching Fuxi to draw the **Eight Trigrams**, thus elucidating the **virtue/power of the divine** and categorizing the **affections of all things**. He established **writing and contracts** to replace the **knotted cords** of governance, observing above and below to formulate the **Dao of marriage, filial piety, and human relationships**.

In the time of **Shennong**, humans consumed wild beasts, raw and uncooked, drinking blood and eating flesh. The *Lǎojūn* then, in the **Qinghan** year, took the title *Dàchéngzǐ*, descending as a teacher to expound the *Yuánjīng Jīng*, instructing them in the **Dao of cultivation and transformation**. Thus, he spread the **hundred grains** to replace roasting and slaughtering, blending the **hundred medicines** to treat the **hundred ailments**. Consequently, when he tasted the **mulberry**, he obtained **rice**; when he tasted the **willow**, he obtained **millet**; when he tasted the **elm**, he obtained **barley**; when he tasted the **sophora**, he obtained **beans**; when he tasted the **peach**, he obtained **small wheat**; when he tasted the **apricot**, he obtained **large wheat**; when he tasted the **hemp**, he obtained **hemp fiber**. As the **five grains** flourished, wild beasts were spared from harm, and the cessation of killing fostered **virtue**, while the removal of evil ensured **life’s preservation**. Without consuming blood and flesh, humanity knew no sickness; with the **five grains** nourishing their nature, no **past karma** remained. His benefits to humanity were immense.

In the time of **Zhufu**, humans still ate raw grains, unaware of cooked food. The *Lǎojūn* then, in the **Tianhan** year, took the title *Guǎngshòuzǐ*, descending as a teacher to expound the *Ànmó Tōngjīng Jīng*, instructing them in the **Dao of kneading and molding vessels** to transform raw grains. Thus, humanity could preserve their **lifespan**.

From the **Lower Three Sovereigns** onward until the time of **Fuxi**, as humans lacked established rites and lived in undifferentiated herds like birds and beasts, the *Lǎojūn* propagated the **Dao’s transformations** across the world, gradually cultivating their **inner awareness**, distinguishing forms and flavors, and applying the **Five Phases**. He widely disseminated scriptures and exhorted the myriad people.

After **Fuxi**, the *Lǎojūn* demonstrated **worldly methods**, establishing **rites and music** to differentiate **rank and hierarchy**, creating **garments and patterns** to distinguish **nobility and commonality**, and constructing **official buildings** to replace **nests and dens**, drawing from the **Great Boldness** trigram.

He fashioned **boats and carriages** to traverse what was impassable, drawing from the **Dispersion** trigram.

He instituted **coffins and burial shrouds**, and the **use of firewood for cremation**, drawing from the **Great Excess** trigram.

The *Lǎojūn* fashioned **bows and arrows** to subdue the disobedient, drawing from the **Opposition** trigram.

He established **laws and punishments** to deter ferocity, drawing from the **Biting** trigram.

He created **writing and contracts** to replace knotted cords, drawing from the **Center** trigram.

And so came the use of **oxen for plowing and horses for riding**, harnessing weight to traverse great distances, drawing from the **Following** trigram.

At midday, markets were held for trade, then dissolved—again drawing from the **Biting** trigram.

Before the invention of **plows, pestles, and mortars**, their benefits were drawn from the **Increase** trigram.

The rule of **double gates and night patrols** was established, drawing from the **Joy** trigram.

Thus, the *Lǎojūn* instructed the sovereigns of his time, transforming the world through his teachings.

In the time of **Huangdi**, the *Lǎojūn* was known as **Guangchengzi**, residing on **Kongtong Mountain**. Huangdi sought him as master, and he expounded the *Daode Jing* and the *Dao Jie Jing*, teaching the **Way of governing the state and cultivating the self**. The Emperor followed these teachings, riding a fire-dragon to ascend to heaven in broad daylight. Here, the *Daode Jing* was first transmitted.

In the time of **Zhuànxū**, the *Lǎojūn* descended as teacher, known as **Chìjīngzi**, residing on **Hengshan**. He instructed the Emperor with the *Wéiyán Jing*, teaching the **Way of loyalty and submission**. The Emperor’s music was praised for its refinement.

In the time of **Yáo**, the *Lǎojūn* descended as teacher, known as **Lùtúzi**, residing by the riverside. He taught the Emperor the *Huángtíng Jing*, instructing in the **Way of purity and harmony**.

In the time of **Emperor Yáo**, the *Lǎojūn* descended as teacher, known as **Wùchéngzi**, residing on **Gūshè Mountain**, and taught the Emperor the *Zhèngshì Líhé Jing*, instructing in the **Way of cautious governance**.

In the time of **Shùn**, the *Lǎojūn* descended as teacher, known as **Yǐnshòuzi**, residing at **Héyáng**, and taught the Emperor the *Daode Jing*, instructing in the **Way of effortless filial piety and fraternal duty**. The Emperor followed these teachings, and the world conformed to his transformation. Hence, Confucius said, *"The one who governs without action—was it not Shùn?"* Thus, the *Daode Jing* was secondly transmitted here.

In the time of **Xià Yǔ**, the *Lǎojūn* descended as teacher, known as **Zhēnxíngzi**, residing in **Shāngshān**, and taught Yǔ the *Déjiè Jing*, instructing in the **Way of diligence and frugality**. He also transmitted the **Língbǎo Wǔfú** and the methods of **summoning ghosts and spirits**, and thus Yǔ followed them, dredging the Nine Rivers and Hundred Streams to connect the Jiang and the sea.

In the time of **Yīn Tāng**, the *Lǎojūn* descended as teacher, known as **Xīzézi**, residing on **Zhēnyīn Mountain** (also read as *Xúnshān*). He taught the Emperor the *Chángshēng Jing*, instructing in the **Way of reverence**.

**Proclamation:**
The **Great Sage, True Primordial Ancestor**, born before the Great Cataclysm, came as teacher to the hundred kings, departed as sovereign of the ten thousand heavens. His scriptures bore countless names, his dragon-virtue pervaded the myriads—his praises are endless.

**Note:** These are matters beyond the six directions—thus omitted in discussion.
As **Zhuangzi** says in the *Qíwùlùn*: *"Beyond the six directions, the Sage exists yet does not speak of them."*
The six directions refer to heaven, earth, and the four cardinal points.
What is spoken of here are matters beyond the six directions, not the scriptures of worldly affairs preserved in existence.
The Sage exists yet does not dare to censure or reject them, hence it is said: *"exists yet does not speak of them."*

The note says: *"Not their overstepping the mark"*—taking the general principle.
As **Zhuangzi** says in the *Xiáoyáo Yóu*: *"Greatly divergent from the path, far from human sentiment."*
*"Divergent"* means excessive deviation.
*"Great medicine"* refers to the grand framework.
These preceding teachings are all discussions of the transcendent—naturally distant from human sentiment.
Not their excessive deviation, but merely outlining the grand framework.
Thus, the note says: *"Matters beyond the six directions—thus omitted in discussion."*
*"Not their overstepping the mark"*—merely citing the general principle.

The heading states: *"The Mother of Laozi was impregnated by a great falling star and conceived. This was manifested in the Li lineage, born in the Shang dynasty, during the seventeenth year of the eighteenth Shang king, Yangjia, in a year of the cycle marked by Gēngshēn. She carried the embryo for eighty-one years, completing the nine-nine number of the Supreme Sun. His mother often wandered beneath the Li tree when Laozi was born. Laozi was born with white hair and thus could speak. Pointing to the Li tree, he said: 'This is my surname.' It is also said that his father’s surname was Li, with given names Wúguǒ or Língfēi. His mother was from the Yin clan, named Yìshòu. He was born in the ninth year of the twenty-second Shang king, Wǔdīng, on the fifteenth day of the second month at the hour of Mǎo, in a year of the cycle marked by Gēngchén."*

The commentary states: *"This is the third section, clarifying the evidence of Laozi’s conception, gestation, and birth, including the era, year, month, and time. Within this section, there are two further divisions for elucidation. The first clarifies the dynasty, year, and season of conception and gestation. The second clarifies the origin of his surname and the era, year, month, and time of his birth."*

The first division, which clarifies the dynasty, year, and season of conception and gestation, states: *"The mother of Laozi was impregnated by a great falling star and conceived, manifesting in the Li lineage."* According to the *Guang Sheng Yi* quoting the *Yuanjun Neichuan*, *"Laozi, in Heaven, is the most honored of all sages. He taught long before the kalpa, maintaining the Dao of non-action as an eternal principle. He transformed into both celestial and human forms, born before countless kalpas, as the sovereign of all sages. Thus, the Yuan Shi Tianzun and Yùchén Dao Jun bestowed upon him the true title of Taishang Laojun, a name held since before the Five Sovereigns across countless kalpas. Though he repeatedly appeared as a teacher to emperors, he had yet to descend into the world and be born. Therefore, in the Nine Purity Realm above, he commanded the Mysterious Jade Maiden to descend into the human realm, becoming the daughter of the Tian Shui Yin clan, marrying Li Lingfei as his wife. Laozi, riding the solar essence and driving a nine-dragon chariot, transformed into a five-colored flowing pearl—or a falling star—and descended into the Mysterious Jade Maiden’s mouth, gestating within her for eighty-one years."*

Again, according to the *Guang Sheng Yi*, *"The one who gestated in wisdom was Laozi, who, pitying the decay of the age, wished to conceal his sageliness and blend with the common, returning to manifest form to save the world. Thus, in the seventeenth year of the eighteenth Shang king, Yangjia, in a year of Gēngshēn, he took form in the womb of the Mysterious Jade Maiden."*

Within this section, there are five further distinctions:
1. The Great Dao manifested and took human form, gestating within a mortal, riding the solar essence as a five-colored symbol, thus illustrating the virtue of the Supreme Sun.
2. Riding the nine-dragon chariot, he condensed and transformed into five-colored mystic yellow, descending into the Mysterious Jade Maiden’s mouth, further illustrating the essence of the nine dragons and the yang vitality.
3. The gestation period in wisdom differed from the common—eighty-one years, completing the nine-nine number of the Supreme Sun, before birth.
4. After the Mysterious Jade Maiden conceived, her appearance grew younger, her spirit serene and at ease. For eighty-one years, she was joyous beyond compare—this was the extraordinary mark of the Sage’s descent.
5. The chamber where the holy mother resided was perpetually harmonious in all seasons, with the six qi balanced—no bitter cold in winter, no oppressive heat in summer. Auspicious light filled the room, sacred winds swept the courtyard, no evil intruded, and all spirits guarded in secret. Thus, eighty-one years passed unnoticed, demonstrating how the great Sage’s conception and gestation differed from that of mortals.

This is the evidence for the Supreme Sage’s conception, gestation, dynasty, and season.

Thus, the heading states: *"The mother of Laozi was impregnated by a great falling star and conceived, manifesting in the Li lineage."*

The second division, which clarifies the origin of his surname and the era, year, month, and time of his birth, states: *"His holy mother often wandered beneath the Li tree when Laozi was born. Laozi was born with white hair and thus could speak. Pointing to the Li tree, he said: 'This is my surname.'"*

When the Sage was betrothed in the Shang dynasty, pitying the decay of the age, he wished to descend as a mortal, manifesting his form to save the world. Thus, he temporarily borrowed a womb to gestate and give birth, greatly displaying his divine transformations to benefit the world. According to the *Benji*, his father’s surname was Li, with given names Wúguǒ, Língfēi, or Qiánhuì. His mother was from the Yin clan, named Yìshòu. In the ninth year of the twenty-second Shang king, Wǔdīng, on the fifteenth day of the second month at the hour of Mǎo, the holy mother happened to be wandering beneath the Li tree when she gave birth to Laozi by splitting her left armpit. Laozi was born able to speak, pointing to the Li tree and saying: *"This is my surname."* He then raised his hand, pointing up and down, declaring: *"Above Heaven, below Heaven, only I am supreme. The sufferings of the world—what joy is there in hearing them? I shall expound the Dao and its laws, universally liberating all sentient beings—animals and plants alike—throughout the ten directions, reaching even the deepest prisons. All who have not yet been liberated shall be liberated."*

Then, countless true sages filled the void, all coming to guard and protect him. The holy ones in the sky praised him with ten titles:
1. Taishang Laojun (The Supreme Venerable Lord)
2. Yuánshénzhì (The Circular Spirit Sage)
3. Wúshàngzūn (The Peerless Sovereign)
4. Dìwángshī (The Emperor’s Teacher)
5. Dàzhàngfū (The Great Man)
6. Dàxiānzūn (The Venerable Immortal)
7. Tiānrénfù (The Father of Heaven and Man)
8. Wúwéishàngrén (The Supreme One of Non-Action)
9. Dàcírézhě (The Great Compassionate and Benevolent One)
10. Zhēnyuànjiàozhǔ (The True Primordial Master of Teaching)

These are the ten titles by which the holy sages in the void praised him.

Suddenly, the nine dragons spat water to bathe his sacred form, and where the water fell, nine wells formed. Today, in the Taqing Palace of Bozhou, they are called the Nine-Dragon Wells, and they remain to this day. This is also as described in the *Huà Hú Jīng*.

Indeed, the great Sage’s descent into the world was marked by such extraordinary signs.

As for the origin of Laozi’s surname Li, the accounts vary greatly.

「Now let us examine the *Great Tang Celestial Filings of the Jade Register* which states: The Sage’s ancestors were originally descendants of **Zhuānxū** (顛顼).
Zhuānxū begot **Dàyè** (大業), who begot **Wāyīn Guā** (娲音瓜).
Wāyīn married a daughter of the **Qiáo** (乔) clan, and upon being illuminated by the **Moonlight of Acclaim** (感月光贯昂), gave birth to **Jiùyáo** (咎繇), whose name was pronounced **Gāo** (皋).
Jiùyáo was pronounced **Yáo** (姚), and he begot **Bóyì** (伯翳).
Bóyì begot **Lǐzhēng** (理征), whose descendants became **shìshī** (士师, officials/judges).
When Lǐzhēng fled the chaos of **Jié** (桀), he retreated to the ruins of **Yīhóu** (伊侯) and sustained himself on **lǐ fruit** (李实), thus changing his surname from **Lǐ** (理) to **Lǐ** (李).
This account states that Jiùyáo’s descendants took **Lǐ** (理) as their surname due to their merit in administering justice, and later, some descendants became the **Lǐ** (里) clan.
It was only when they sought refuge in the ruins of Yīhóu that they changed the surname **Lǐ** (里) to **Lǐ** (李).
Lǐzhēng begot **Lìzhēn** (利贞), who lived in the time of **Yīn Shāng** (殷汤).
Lìzhēn begot **Chāngzǔ** (昌祖), who served as a **great official** (大夫) in the state of **Chén** (陈) and settled in **Kǔ County** (苦县).
Chāngzǔ begot **Míng** (明), who became the **Chancellor** (相) of Chén and was enshrined in a temple north of **Lài Xiāng** (濑乡), giving rise to **Xiàngchéng** (相城).
Míng begot **Qìngbīn** (庆宾), who begot **Língfēi** (灵飞), also known as **Qiánhuì** (虔会).
Both Qìngbīn and Língfēi ascended to heaven in broad daylight.
The text earlier mentions that they took the **plum tree** (桃树, *táoshù*) as their surname, hence the surname **Lǐ** (李).
Examining this, the surname may have been **Lǐ** (理), **Lǐ** (里), or **Lǐ** (李), though their pronunciations were the same, their characters differed.
This shifting of surnames according to different eras is not reliable.
Only the account of taking the **plum tree** (桃树) as the surname, as attested by **Master Dù Tiānshī** (杜天师), is correct.

According to **Xuē Dàohéng** (薛道衡) of the **Sui Dynasty** in his *Laozi Stele* (《老君碑》):
*"Illuminated by the sun at his birth, his origins in receiving qi are unfathomable.
He took the **plum tree** (桃树) as his surname, yet the source of his **blowing the bamboo flute and establishing the Dao** (吹律之本) remains unclear."*

Thus, the account of taking the **plum tree** (桃树) as his surname seems most plausible.

Next, let us consider the accounts of his descent and birth era.
According to the *Comprehensive Meanings of the Holy Saints* (《广圣义》):
The Sage Laozi is the **originator of the Dao** (至道之祖), the **founder of primordial transformation** (元化之宗).
He existed before the **uppermost antiquity** (上古) yet was not its earliest, and after the **final age** (末代) yet was not its latest.
How much more so before countless **kalpas** (劫)!
He already propagated the Dao and its teachings, so how could one say he was born from a womb and thus claim it as his birth?
When we speak of his descent, it is to manifest his presence in the human world and demonstrate that he had a beginning.
His birth form was the **Holy Mother** (圣母), showing that he had a birth.
The Holy Mother served the **Primordial Lord** (元君), indicating his exalted status.
Now, examining the various scriptures, his descent and birth are recorded in three instances.

The first descent and birth:
In the **seventh year of the reign of Shānhé** (上和七年), during the **year of Gēngyín** (庚寅) in the ninth month on the **third day of Jiǎzǐ** (甲子),
he was born between the **Lǐ Valley** (李谷) and **Huánguǎn Língjìng Mountain** (玄罡灵镜山) in the **Northern Mystic Realm** (北玄女国).
The Holy Mother was called **Mother of Mystic Void** (玄虚之母).
At the time of his birth, three suns emerged from the east, and nine dragons spat water to bathe his form.
He thus took his name from the Lǐ Valley, being called **Huángyuán** (玄元), with the **character name Zǐguāng** (子光).
He was the **highest of the exalted** (高上之冑), the **offspring of the Jade Sovereign** (玉皇之胤),
and held the title **Lord of Supreme Longevity, Great Master of Peace, True One of Grand Unity, and the Golden Gate Sage Emperor** (长生大主太平正真太一君金阙后圣九玄帝君).

Upon careful examination, this was also before the kalpa, with **Zhūlíng Shānhé** (朱灵上和) as the reign title of the previous kalpa.

The second descent and birth:
In the **ninth year of the twenty-second sovereign of Yīn** (殷之二十二王武丁九年), during the **year of Gēngchén** (庚辰) in the second month on the **fifteenth day at the hour of Mǎo** (卯时),
he was born.
The Holy Mother was called **Mystic Marvelous Jade Maiden** (玄妙玉女), who was the **Teacher of the Supreme Deity** (上帝之师),
later ascending to the title **Primordial Lord of Grand Unity** (太一元君).
This account, upon careful review, corresponds to the era of his descent in **Bózhōu** (亳州).
It is the same as the **Taqing Palace** (太清宫) in present-day **Wèizhēn County** (卫真县), marking the site of his descent and birth.

According to **Huángfǔ Shì'ān** (皇甫士安)'s *Long Chronicle* (长历), the **year of Jiǎzǐ** (甲子) is confirmed.
**Master Gé Xiānshī** (葛仙公) stated that the **Grand Age** (太岁) was **Dīngmǎo** (丁卯),
indicating the era of the **Chou Dynasty** (周师).
This was the **first year of King Zhòu** (纣元年, **Dīngwèi** 丁未) to the **twenty-first year of King Zhòu** (纣二十一年, **Dīngmǎo** 丁卯).
Laozi resided on the **south-facing slope of Qíshān Mountain** (岐山之阳) as the **Teacher of King Xī of Chou** (周西伯之师),
and was known as **Zǐ of Xiānyì** (燮邑子).
From the ninth year of Yīn Wǔdīng (殷武丁九年, **Gēngchén** 庚辰) to the twenty-first year of King Zhòu (纣二十一年, **Dīngmǎo** 丁卯),
spanning **one hundred and eighty years**.
He then ascended to heaven in the **twenty-fifth year of King Zhāo** (昭王二十五年, **Guǐchǒu** 癸丑) in the fourth month on the **twenty-eighth day**,
after which, in the **year of Yǐmǎo** (乙卯), he manifested a **divine incarnation** (分身降) near the **western bank of Jǐnjiāng River** (锦江之滨) in **Xīshǔ** (西蜀),
taking residence in the home of a **great official** (大官).
In the **twenty-ninth year of King Zhāo** (昭王二十九年, **Dīngsì** 丁巳),
**Yín Xǐ** (尹喜) arrived in Shǔ.
Originally, there was no **green sheep market** (青羊肆),
but when the **Primordial Sage** (太上) was in the **Tàiwéi constellation** (太微), he first exerted his influence over the **Green Boy** (青童) of the **Green Emperor** (青帝),
descending to the capital of Shǔ and transforming into a **green sheep** (青羊).
Yín Xǐ saw a man leading it, and suddenly realized:
*"Since there is a green sheep, and it is being led to its market, this must be the Primordial Sage’s arrangement."*
He then asked the man leading the sheep:
*"To which family does this sheep belong?"*
The man replied:
*"My wife, though she has reached old age, gave birth to a child whose crying never ceases.
She cast him into water and fire, yet neither could harm him.
A **Daoist practitioner** (道者) said:
'If you let the green sheep nurse him, his crying will stop.'"*

The third descent and birth:
According to the *Yóulóng Transmission* (《犹龙传》) quoting the *Húnyuán Original Records* (《混元本纪》):
The **Primordial Sage** (太上) ascended to heaven in the **year of Jiǎyín** (甲寅) of King Zhāo of Chou (周昭王).
This was the **twenty-sixth year** (二十六年) of King Zhāo, yet the month and day of his ascension were not recorded.
Later, in the **commentary by Zāng Qú** (张渠) on the *Northern Dipper Scripture* (《北斗经》) seen in **Xīshǔ** (西蜀),
it states:
*"The Primordial Sage ascended to heaven in the twenty-sixth year of King Zhāo of Chou (周昭王二十六年, **Jiǎyín** 甲寅), on the fourth month’s twenty-eighth day.
In the year of **Yǐmǎo** (乙卯), he manifested a divine incarnation near the western bank of Jǐnjiāng River (锦江之滨) in Xīshǔ,
taking residence in the home of a great official."*

The **Primordial Sage** then said, *"I dwell in the **Tàiwēi** [Great Pivot], my true form is **Zhēnyī** [True Unity], **Tàihé** [Great Harmony] descends in purity, and my radiant spirit manifests as a human. As host and guest mutually arise, I leave my trace here—why should you find it strange?"*

**Yǐn Xǐ** then knelt and bowed twice, saying, *"This is a joyous assembly, and I humbly present myself before Your Heavenly Presence. May I ask if Your Benevolent Majesty has come forth or remains within, and if You dwell in peace?"*

The **Primordial Sage** smiled and replied, *"Since we parted, what have you gained or lost? You have preserved the **Dao/Way** and guarded the **One**—how could this not be beneficial?"*

**Yǐn Xǐ** said, *"I have reverently served the **secret essentials**, and through them, I have attained their mysteries. Your saving grace surpasses even that of Heaven and Earth."*

The **Primordial Sage** declared, *"I once left you to dwell in this world. After a thousand days of pure fasting, I awaited you here. Now you have preserved your form and refined your **qi**, already reaching the **Míngmiào** [Dark Mysteries], and your heart is bound by the **zǐluò** [purple snares], while your face bears the **yuánmíng** [circular clarity]. Your golden name is inscribed in the **true diagram**, and your jade **zhá** [tablet] is tied to the **purple chamber**. Your **qi** harmonizes with **Tàiwēi**, and your form dissolves into **Zhēnyī**—thus you are now qualified to serve."*

Upon finishing his words, the **sacred beings of the Three Realms** (三界圣真) arrived with ten thousand chariots and a hundred thousand horsemen floating through the air. They then bestowed upon **Yǐn Xǐ**:
- the **zǐfúróng** [purple lotus-crown],
- the **fēiqīngyǔ** [flying green-feathered skirt],
- the **dānzhǔlǜshǒu** [crimson gaze and verdant sleeves],
- the **jiāodài nícháng** [crossed sash of rainbow clouds],
- the **luówén huángguǎ** [embroidered robe with yellow belt],
and appointed him as **Wénshǐ** [Origin of Scriptures] **Master**, granting him the title of **Wúshàng Zhēnrén** [Supreme True Person]. From that time onward, he was permitted to attend the **Lóngchē** [Dragon Chariot], freely traversing the heavens above and the earth below.

The **Primordial Sage** then ascended his seat and expounded the *Yuányáng Scripture* (《元阳经》) to the mother, who resided in the southwest of **Chéngdū** by several hundred paces. In the **second year of Zhōnghé** (中和二年), he received the **Língchuán** [Divine Transmission] edict and established the **Qīngyáng Temple** (青羊宫).

This was indeed the **third descent and birth** in accordance with the decree.

Now, the passage cited in this section refers to the **second descent and birth** in **Bózhōu** [Bozhou].

The text states:
*"The **Primordial Sage**’s stature was eight *chǐ* and eight *cùn* tall, with a yellow complexion. His holy visage was golden, hence ‘yellow’ is mentioned. His forehead was broad (广颡), and his ears were large and drooping (聃耳). His eyes were vast, seeing all (大目). His teeth were wide and well-spaced (疏齿). His mouth was square (方口), not meaning its shape was four-sided, but that he spoke of **Dao/Way** and righteousness (道义) with precision. Even **Confucius** was called ‘river-eyed and sea-mouthed’ (河目海口), both being marks of the sage’s extraordinary features. His lips were thick (厚唇), and his brow bore the **sānyùdálǐ** [three-five enlightened patterns]—‘lǐ’ meaning ‘text’ or ‘mark.’ His brow seemed to bear the characters ‘three-five’ (三五), a luminous script. His forehead also resembled the **rìjiǎo yuèxuán** [sun-horn and moon-eyebrow], as if the sun and moon were inscribed there—near or far, deep or shallow, they illuminated all without being physically present. His face was full and round like a moon. His nose had a double ridge (鼻有双骨), indicating three nasal openings (三窍). His ears also had three openings (耳有三漏). His feet bore the **èrwǔ** [two-noon] marks (足蹈二午), and his hands held the **shíwén** [ten-characters] (手握十文). This means each hand had ten characters’ worth of markings, much like **Great Yù** (大禹), whose left hand bore the character ‘water’ (水), and right hand bore ‘platform’ (台), combining to form ‘governance’ (治). These are the extraordinary features of the sage. His **qi** was supremely pure, and his received form was most unusual. Indeed, from ancient times, sages have all possessed extraordinary features—how much more so for the **Primordial Sage**, who embodies the **greatest virtue/power** (大圣之德), with seventy-two **ruìxiàng** [auspicious marks] and eighty-one **zhǒnghǎo** [distinct virtues]? His celestial visage was dignified, and his holy features were uniquely refined; though I cannot enumerate them all, they certainly exceed these few examples."*

The second part clarifies the **Primordial Sage**’s birthplace:
*"The **Primordial Sage** was born in **Chǔguó** [State of Chu], **Kǔ County** (苦县), **Làiyáng Township** (濑阳乡), **Qǔrén Village** (曲仁里), beside the **Wō Water** (涡水). According to the *Tàidīng Yùjié* (大唐天渍玉牒) of the **Táng Dynasty** (大唐), the sage’s ancestor, **Chāngzǔ** (昌祖), served as a great official under the **Chén Dynasty** (陈) and settled in **Kǔ County**. **Chāngzǔ**’s son, **Míng** (明), became the **Chén Dynasty**’s chancellor and was buried north of **Làiyáng Township**—a temple was then established there. Today’s reference to **Chǔguó** may suggest **Yǐngzhōu** (郢州), which was ancient **Chu**. **Kǔ County** was its subordinate jurisdiction.

Additionally, in **Bózhōu** (亳州), **Chéngfǔ County** (城父县) to the east by thirty *lǐ*, there is the **Tiānjìng Temple** (天静官), where the **sage-mother** conceived. A **flowing star** (流星) is said to have appeared at the **original daytime chamber** (原昼寝堂) there. **Chéngfǔ County** was also part of ancient **Chu**.

Examine closely: the **Primordial Sage** conceived in the **Tiānjìng Temple** of **Chéngfǔ**, descended in the **Tàiqīng Temple** (太清宫) of **Kǔ County**. **Kǔ County** was the ancient name of the region. During the **Hàn** and **Wèi** eras, it became **Gǔyáng County** (谷阳县). By the **first year of Qiánfēng** (乾封元年) in the **Táng Dynasty**, it was renamed **Zhēnyuán County** (真源县). In the **second year of Zhōnghé** (中和二年), it was elevated to **Chì County** (赤县). During the reign of **Emperor Zhēnzōng of Sòng** (宋真宗朝), it was changed to **Wèizhēn County** (卫真县), which is today’s **Wèizhēn County** (卫真县), **Làiyáng Township** (濑阳乡), **Gǔyáng Town** (谷阳镇). The **Tàiqīng Temple** (太清宫) is the place."*

The **Wōshuǐ** region on its **yin** side—now the **Tàiqīng Temple** on the right bank of the **Wō River**—hence called *yin* (or *bīn*, meaning "bank"). This was the homeland where the **Primordial Sage** dwelled.
