「According to the *Guangsheng Yi* [广圣义], it states: The **Laozi** [老子] was born from the **jewel embryo** [琼胎], nurtured by **Supreme Wisdom** [寄慧] for eighty-one years, and upon his sacred birth, he was born with a snowy-white head. The **Supreme Mother** [圣母] thus bestowed upon him his name to reveal this to the world.

Within this **Dao/Way-teaching** [道] tradition, there are five distinct interpretations of his name:

1. The **Supreme Clarity** [圣人] descended into the mortal realm, differing from the common folk. The **Supreme Mother** [圣母] named him **"Lao"** [老] because he was born aged, and **"zi"** [子] because he was newborn. As he was also born with a white head, these two terms were combined, thus he is called **Laozi** [老子].

2. He illuminates the **Dao/Way** [道] in opposition to worldly conventions. **"Lao"** [老] signifies longevity, while **"zi"** [子] denotes youth. Though mortals age from youth to old age, the **Supreme Clarity** [太上] was aged at birth and later attained youth, thus clarifying his retreat from the world to return to his primordial essence.

3. **"Lao"** [老] means "examine" or "test," for he scrutinizes all sages. **"Zi"** [子] means "procreate," for he gives birth to all things. Thus, the **Old Master** [老君] is the progenitor of all beings and the patriarch of all sages, hence his name as **"Laozi"** [老子]—examiner and progenitor.

4. The **Supreme Clarity** [圣人] bestows his name in reverse, from end to beginning. **"Lao"** [老] signifies the end, while **"zi"** [子] signifies the beginning. Though mortals begin with youth and end with age, the **Old Master** [老君] begins with age and returns to youth, urging all to cultivate the **Dao/Way** [道] by reversing aging and returning to infancy. Hence, he is called **Laozi** [老子].

5. He abandons traces and harmonizes with the world, conforming to its ways. **"Lao"** [老] is used because he was born with a white head, hence appearing aged. **"Zi"** [子] is a common term for males, akin to how **Confucius** [孔子], **Mencius** [孟子], **Zhuangzi** [庄子], and **Liezi** [列子] are named by their surnames. **Laozi** [老子], **Huguanzi** [鹖冠子], **Baopuzi** [抱朴子], and **Huainanzi** [淮南子] derive their names from their teachings or deeds. The **Preface to the Secrets** [序诀] states: The name **Laozi** [老子] originated from countless **kalpas** [劫] ago, its meaning vast and profound, stretching infinitely into the distant past. This is not because he was aged at birth but because he existed long before countless **kalpas** [劫], hence the name **Lao** [老]. Indeed, he was born from the **Supreme Mother** [圣母], emerging from her left flank, his head already snowy-white, and thus named **Laozi** [老子]. His name **Laozi** [老子] arose from the **Mysterious** [玄], predating heaven and earth, without the bounds of aging or decline, hence **Laozi** [老子]. This is the testimony of the **Preface to the Secrets** [序诀].

Examining these interpretations closely, his name was not conferred due to his aged appearance at birth. Rather, the **Old Master** [老君] taught the **Dao/Way** [道] across countless **kalpas** [劫], manifested his form, and perpetually appeared aged, thus earning the name **Laozi** [老子]. The name **Laozi** [老子] emerged at this time, but the title **Old Master** [老君] predates the countless **kalpas** [劫] before it.

It is also said: When the **Old Master** [老君] was about to reveal the great teachings and spread the **Dao/Way-transformations** [化] across the world, he declared: *"The **Dao/Way** [道] cannot lack a revered teacher, and the teachings cannot lack a sovereign master."* Thus, he became a disciple of the **Supreme Clarity, Yucun** [太上玉宸大道君], who is the **Divine Lord of Primordial Beginning** [元始天尊]'s student. The **Divine Lord of the **Dao/Way** [道君] is the origin of **Dao/Way** [道] and the source of its penetration, born before countless **kalpas** [劫], as the ancestor of **Dao-essence** [道炁]. Hence, he is called the **Great Divine Lord of the **Dao/Way** [大道君]. The **Divine Lord of Primordial Beginning** [元始天尊] is the sovereign of countless heavens and the ruler of countless worlds, born before the vast **kalpa** [浩劫], as the fundamental root of **Dao-essence** [道炁].

The **Divine Lord of Primordial Beginning** [元始天尊], the **Supreme Clarity, Yucun** [太上大道君], and the **Old Master** [老君] span both celestial and earthly realms, their transformations boundless. They were born before countless **kalpas** [劫] and endure eternally thereafter, revered by all heavens and followed by all emperors, thus bestowed the true title **Supreme Clarity, Old Master** [太上老君]. The three sages, as teachers, established the hierarchy of those who transmit the teachings.

**"Tai"** [太] denotes the utmost extent of greatness. **"Shang"** [上] denotes the utmost height. **"Lao"** [老] denotes the utmost longevity. **"Jun"** [君] denotes the utmost reverence. Thus, the **Supreme Clarity, Old Master** [太上老君] is the most exalted in greatness, height, longevity, and reverence, surpassing the **Five Supreme Clarities** [五太], embodying the full essence of the **Four Extremes** [四极]. Hence, he is called **Supreme Clarity, Old Master** [太上老君]. The title **Old Master** [老君] originates from this.

Moreover, **"Tai Shang"** [太上] is explained in the *Guangsheng Yi* [广圣义] as the sovereign title for the **Dao/Way-teaching** [教] and the ultimate attainment of **sainthood** [圣]. It is further elucidated: **"Tai"** [太] means "great," with none greater than **"Tai"** [太]. **"Shang"** [上] means "high," with none higher than **"Shang"** [上]. Thus, it signifies the highest rank of one who cultivates **Dao/Way** [道] and attains ultimate fruition.

Similarly, mortals who practice **Dao/Way** [道] progress from the common to **Dao/Way** [道], from **Dao/Way** [道] to **immortality** [仙], from **immortality** [仙] to **authentic** [真], and from **authentic** [真] to **sage** [圣]. The ultimate rank of **sainthood** [圣] ascends to **Tai Shang** [太上]. **Tai Shang** [太上] possesses all six **perfections** [六通] and ten thousand **virtues/powers** [万德], inheriting the **Dharma-ruler’s** [法王] position and overseeing all sages, thus attaining this sovereign and ultimate title. Just as worldly emperors, succeeding in their lineage, are called **Tai Shang Huangdi** [太上皇], so too is this.

Since the **Divine Lord of Primordial Beginning** [元始天尊], there have been **Tai Shang Da Dao Jun** [太上大道君], **Tai Shang Lao Jun** [太上老君], **Tai Shang Zhangren** [太上丈人], and **Tai Shang Gao Huangdi** [太上高皇帝]. Though they share this sovereign and ultimate title, they do not transmit the teachings.

Only the **Great Divine Lord of the **Dao/Way** [大道君] and the **Supreme Clarity, Old Master** [太上老君] are the sovereigns of all heavens and the patriarchs of all teachings. Thus, in the **Three Caverns and Four Auxiliaries** [三洞四辅], as well as in all scriptures, the title **"Tai Shang"** [太上] is prepended to their names, signifying that **"Tai Shang"** [太上] is the sovereign title for the **Dao/Way-teaching** [教] and the ultimate attainment of **sainthood** [圣].

The names **Laozi** [老子], **Old Master** [老君], and **Supreme Clarity** [太上] have been briefly explained above. Yet, the **Supreme Clarity** [太上] conforms to the **Dharma** [法] and manifests his name through the ages, with the number of his **kalpas** [劫] as boundless as the sands of the **Huan River** [洹]. Why so?

According to the *Xisheng Jing* [西升经], since the beginning of this world, the changes have been as numerous as the sands of the earth, and the slightest movement brings forth a **kalpa** [劫]. Indeed, the **Old Master** [老君] has endured countless hardships.

The *Youlong Zhuan* [犹龙传] further states: The **Old Master** [老君] was born in the **void** [空洞], his transformations natural and spontaneous. His wisdom is boundless, his **virtue/power** [圣德] complete. His form cannot be measured, and his names are without end. In heaven, he is the sovereign of all heavens; among sages, he is the ruler of all sages; among **immortals** [仙], he is the total of all **immortals** [仙]; among the **authentic** [真], he is the first of all **authentic** [真]; among the stars, he is the **Celestial Emperor** [天皇大帝]; in teaching, he is the **Supreme Clarity, Old Master** [太上老君]. Sometimes he manifests a thousand two hundred names, sometimes reveals one hundred eighty titles, sometimes as the **Father of Non-Action** [无为父], sometimes as the **Mother of All Things** [万物母]. He cycles with the **Great Dao** [大道], as the root of heaven and earth. His vast and boundless presence cannot be named exhaustively.

chunks.original_text: 故碧虚题云：论老子之号，言其略也。 今按诸经，广而伸之，言其详也。 太上之德，岂不大哉。 题曰：夫人受命，自有通神达见者。 禀气与常人不同，应为道主。 故能为天神所济，众仙所从，是以所出度世之法，若九丹八石，玉醴金液，存真守元，思神历藏，行气炼形，消灾辟恶，治鬼养性，绝谷变化，厌固教戒，役使鬼魅，皆老子常所经历救世之术，非至至者也。 已而治家治世，皆大道之土牧雅切。 苴侧雅切。 ，圣人之余事也。 疏曰：此第十二门明太上具神通力，应为道主，垂世立教，千方万法，以救於人也。 就此门中，复分为二。 其一论具神通力，应为道主。 其二明垂世立教，以救於人。 一者具神通力，应为道主者。 题云夫人承命，自有通神达见者。 见字，疑作变字。 神者，伸也。 其字从示从申，谓出而有所示，入而无所屈。 示者显然出示於人也。 申者舒伸而无所穷屈也。 此神之妙用也。 夫人能虚静则合道，动用则显神。 《易系》云：神也者，妙万物而为言者也。 又曰：阴阳不测之谓神。 是知神者，倏有忽无，推移变化，幽隐而不可测度者也。 故我太上老君为万道之宗，众教之祖，自有通神达变之妙，以为大道之主，固非常人所能及也。 遂感天地神只，无不赞仰，千真万圣，无不归依者，不亦宜乎。 故曰：具神通力，应为道主者，良以此欤。 其二垂世立教，以救於人者，题日是以所出度世之法，若九丹八石。 九丹者：一曰丹华，二日神符，三曰神丹，四曰还丹，五曰饵丹，六日炼丹，七曰柔丹，八曰伏丹，九曰寒丹。 八石者：一曰玄精石，二日云母石，三曰花蕊石，四日炉洽石，五日寒水石，六日阳起石，七曰赤石脂，八曰白石脂。 又按《抱朴子》：八石者，丹砂、雄黄、雌黄、石留黄、曾青、矾石、磁石、戎盐。 此九丹八石者，各有褥炼之法。 玉醴金液，《藏典》有消玉为醴、镕金作液之法。 存真守元，思神历藏，行气炼形，《藏典》有存三守一，行气思神，内以炼藏，外以炼形，皆修行之法。 消灾辟恶，《科典》有祈祷之法。 治鬼符箓有驱治考召之法。 养性，经教有守静澄心调习之法。 绝谷《经论》有服气、服丹、服水、服符休粮之法。 变化，《洞经》 有分形散影，升腾变化之法。 厌固洞神教中有禳祀之法。 教戒，正一部中有屏绝世务禁忌之法。 役使鬼魅。 《法箓》有役使鬼神之诀。 如上诸法，皆我碧虚真人略言之，有此数种，至於千方万法，不可徧举，是皆太上常所经历救世之卫，非至至者也。 已而治家治国，以至於天下，皆大道之土直，圣人之余事也。 此《庄子让王篇》曰：道之真，以治身，其绪余以为国家，土直以治天下。 绪余者，譬如躁丝先须抽绪而后见丝，丝譬则真也，绪譬则赢也，绪犹不真，况其余者乎。 又如择菜者，菜其真也。 土直为粪壤，黄直不精粹之物也。 以上诸法，皆随机设教救世浅末之方，故碧虚以为非至至而皆大道之土苴，圣人之余事也，不亦宜乎。 至至者，道之真以治身者是也。 题曰：老子恬然无为，专以长生为务，故在周虽久而名位不迁者，盖欲和光同尘，内实自然，所以贵道虚无，因应变化於无为，故着书称微妙难识，而道成乃去，是所谓博大真人也。

The **Emerald Void** [碧虚] thus states: *"This discourse on the names of Laozi is a brief account."* Now, examining all the scriptures and expanding upon it, we speak of the full details. The **Supreme Virtue/Power** [太上之德]—how vast is it not?

The text reads: *"Since one receives the mandate, there are those who inherently possess divine penetration and transcendent insight."* Endowed with **qi** [气] unlike common mortals, they should naturally be the sovereigns of the **Dao** [道]. Thus, they can be aided by the **Celestial Deities** [天神], followed by all **immortals** [仙]. Therefore, the methods they propagate to deliver the world—such as the **Nine Elixirs and Eight Stones** [九丹八石], **jade nectar and golden liquid** [玉醴金液], preserving the **True Essence** [真] and guarding the **Original** [元], contemplating the **spirit** [神] and traversing the **inner chambers** [藏], cultivating **qi** [气] and refining the form, dispelling calamities and warding off evils, commanding ghosts and nourishing the nature, abstaining from grains and undergoing transformation, averting rigid constraints and issuing precepts, or enslaving specters and demons—all these are the **Supreme Clarity, Old Master**’s [太上老君] habitual practices for saving the world, not the ultimate of the ultimate.

Moreover, in governing households and states, even extending to the realm, these are but the **Dao**’s [道] earthly shepherds and the **Sages**’ [圣人] secondary affairs. As the **Zhuangzi’s "Let the King Rule"** [《庄子让王篇》] states: *"The **True Dao** [道之真] is used to govern the self; its remnants are applied to the state, and earthly shepherds to rule the world."* The remnants are like the coarse threads of silk—first, one must extract the refined strands before the silk is revealed. Silk is the **True Essence** [真], while the remnants are the **coarse** [赢]. The remnants are not yet the **True Essence** [真], how much less so their leavings?

Again, as in selecting vegetables: the **True Essence** [真] is the vegetable itself. Earthly shepherds are but the **dung and soil** [粪壤], coarse and unrefined things. All the aforementioned methods are expedient teachings tailored to the circumstances for superficial deliverance of the world. Hence, the **Emerald Void** [碧虚] concludes that these are not the ultimate of the ultimate, but rather the **Dao**’s [道] earthly shepherds and the **Sages**’ [圣人] secondary affairs—is this not fitting?

The ultimate of the ultimate is the **True Dao** [道之真] used to govern the self. The text states: *"Laozi was tranquil and non-acting, solely devoted to longevity. Thus, though he remained long in the Zhou dynasty without advancing in rank or position, he sought to harmonize with the mundane, internally embodying naturalness. He valued the **Dao**’s [道] subtle and void essence, adapting to transformations through non-action, and so wrote books of profound mystery and unrecognizability, while the **Dao** [道] was achieved, he departed—this is the so-called Broad and Great **True Person** [博大真人]."*

chunks.original_text: 疏曰：此第十三门明太上以恬淡无为，守之於内，和光同尘，应之於外，是所谓博大真人也。 题曰老子恬淡无为，专以长生为务者。 《南华经刻意篇》云：夫恬淡寂寞，虚无无为，此天地之平，道德之质也。 故圣人休休焉，则平易矣。 平易则恬淡矣。 平易恬淡，则忧息不能入，邪气不能袭，故其德全而神不亏，此长生之道也。 故碧虚称太上恬淡无为，专以长生为务者，以此。 次云在周虽久，而名位不迁者。 夫老君自文、武历成、康，及昭王时出关，至幽、厉、平、定之世，前后数百年，止不过藏史、柱史、太史之职而已。 故云在周虽久，而名位不迁也。 盖欲和光同尘，尘，之於外，虚无自然，实之於内，如有世务，因其所感，不得已而应之，抑又守无为之道，顺变化之理，故云虚无因应也。 《庄子刻意篇》云：感而后应，迫而后动，不得已而后起也。 夫太上之道，出处语默也如此，岂常人之所能测者哉。 故碧虚叹云：其着书也称微妙难识，道成乃去，是所谓博大真人也。 经云：古之善为士者，微妙玄通，深不可识。 《庄子大宗师篇》云：真人之息以踵，众人之息以喉，其嗜欲深者天机浅，是知真人之容，道根深远，众人固不识也。 何则？ 庄子云：纯素之道，唯神是守，守而勿失，与神为一，一之精通，合乎天伦。 天，自然也。 伦，理也。 既与神为一，则精智无碍，故冥乎自然之理也。 野语有之曰：众人重利，康士重名，贤士尚志，圣人贵精。 故素也者，谓其无所与杂也，纯也者，谓其不亏其神也。 能体纯素，谓之真人。 且常人至此犹日真人，况我太上老君为万道之祖，众教之宗。 故碧虚引《南华经天下篇》云：以深为根，以约为纪，曰坚则毁矣，锐则挫矣，常宽容於物，不削於人，可谓至极。 关尹老聘乎，古之博大真人哉，不亦宜乎。 题曰：且老子之子孙，祭杞不辗，而升於玉京。 庄子之鼓盆送妻，而入侍帝宸，皆为道之宗师者，故使后世之人，信其长生可学，非神异而学不能及也。 是曰方外之教，有淳古之风焉。 疏曰：此第十四门明太上、庄子，亦有妻室子孙，然为大道之宗师者，欲使世人知长生之道，可方学而致，非神异而学不能及也。 题曰：且老子之子孙，祭祀不辍，而升於玉京者。 经云：善建者不技，善抱者不脱，子孙祭祀不辍，此本经第五十四章之文也。 其旨已具本章中消释。 升玉京者，《度人经》云：郁罗萧台，玉山上京，上极无上，大罗玉清，渺渺劫仞，若亡若存，此三清上圣之所居也。 举大罗玉清，则上清、太清在其中可知矣。 故云升於玉京也。 次云庄子鼓盆送妻，而入侍帝宸者。 《南华经至乐篇》云：庄子妻死，惠子吊之，庄子方箕踞，音锯，言垂足踞傲而坐也。 鼓盆而歌。 惠子曰：与人居，长子，老，身死，不哭亦足矣。 又鼓盆而歌，不亦甚乎。 庄子曰：不然，是其始死也，我独何能无巢，然察其始而本无生，非徒无生也，而本无形，非徒无形也，而本无气，杂乎芒苜之间，变而有气，气变而有形，形变而有生，今又变而之死，是相与为春秋冬夏四时行也。 人且偃然寝于巨室，以天地为室也。 我噭噭然随而哭之，自以为不通命，故止也。 又云：入侍帝宸者，按《丹台新录》云：庄子升为太玄博士，乃仙职也。

The commentary states: This is the **Thirteenth Gate**, which elucidates how the **Supreme Sage** [太上] maintained inner tranquility through **serene simplicity and non-action**, while outwardly harmonizing with the world. This is what is called the **Broad and Great True Person** [博大真人]. The text states: *"Laozi was serene and non-acting, solely devoted to longevity."*

The *Southern Flower Scripture* [《南华经》] *Chapter on Intentions* [《刻意篇》] says:
*"Serene simplicity, stillness, and emptiness—this is the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth, the essence of **Dao** and **virtue** [道德]. Thus, the **Sage** rests in repose, and so attains simplicity. Simplicity leads to serene simplicity. When serene and simple, worries cannot enter, and malevolent **qi** cannot assail. Thus, his **virtue** is complete, and his spirit unharmed—this is the **Way** of longevity."*

Therefore, the **Emerald Void** [碧虚] praises the **Supreme Sage** as one who was serene and non-acting, solely devoted to longevity, for this very reason.

Next, it states: *"Though he remained long in the Zhou dynasty without advancing in rank or position."* Indeed, Laozi, from the time of **Wen** and **Wu** through **Cheng** and **Kang**, until the reign of **Zhao Wang**, departed the pass during the **You** and **Li** dynasties, spanning hundreds of years. Yet, he held only the positions of **Historian** [藏史], **Pillar Historian** [柱史], or **Grand Historian** [太史]. Thus, it is said: *"Though he remained long in the Zhou dynasty without advancing in rank or position."*

He sought to harmonize with the world externally, while internally embodying emptiness and naturalness. When worldly affairs arose, he responded only when compelled, adhering to the **Way** of non-action and aligning with the principles of transformation. Hence, it is said: *"He adapted through emptiness and non-action."*

The *Zhuangzi* *Chapter on Intentions* states:
*"Only when moved does one respond; only when pressed does one act; only when unavoidable does one rise."*

The **Supreme Sage’s** **Dao** in retreat, presence, speech, and silence was thus—how could ordinary people comprehend it? Therefore, the **Emerald Void** sighs: *"His writings were profound and unrecognizable; when the **Dao** was achieved, he departed—this is what is called the **Broad and Great True Person**."*

The scripture says:
*"The ancients who excelled as scholars were subtle, mysterious, and profound—deeply unrecognizable."*

The *Zhuangzi* *Chapter on the Great Master* states:
*"The **True Person’s** breathing reaches the soles of his feet, while commoners breathe at their throats. Those with deep desires have shallow **Heavenly Mechanism** [天机]. Thus, the **True Person’s** demeanor is rooted in **Dao**, profound and distant—commoners cannot recognize it."*

Why? *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The **Way** of purity and simplicity is guarded solely by the spirit. Guard it without loss, and it merges with the spirit. When perfectly unified, it aligns with **Heavenly Order** [天伦]. **Heaven** is nature; **Order** is principle. Once merged with the spirit, wisdom flows unimpeded, thus attaining the mysterious and natural."*

A folk saying goes:
*"Commoners value profit, the virtuous value fame, the worthy value aspiration, and the **Sage** values purity."*

Thus, *purity* means unmixed, and *simplicity* means untainted spirit. To embody purity and simplicity is to be a **True Person**. Even ordinary people call this the **True Person**—how much more so for **Laozi**, the ancestor of all **Dao**s and the master of all teachings?

Therefore, the **Emerald Void** cites the *Southern Flower Scripture* *Chapter on the World* [《天下篇》]:
*"Rooted in depth, governed by restraint—rigidity invites destruction, sharpness invites blunting. Always accommodating to things, never diminishing others—this is the ultimate."*

**Guan Yin** and **Lao Dan**—were they not the **Broad and Great True Persons** of antiquity? Is this not fitting?

The text states: *"Moreover, Laozi’s descendants performed unceasing sacrifices at **Qi** [杞], ascending to **Yujing** [玉京]. **Zhuangzi**, beating his basin to send off his wife, then entered to serve the **Celestial Sovereign** [帝宸]—both were masters of the **Dao**, causing later generations to believe that longevity was attainable through study, not through supernatural feats alone."*

This is called the **Teaching Beyond the Square** [方外之教], preserving the pure antiquity.

The commentary states: This is the **Fourteenth Gate**, which clarifies that the **Supreme Sage** and **Zhuangzi**, though they had wives, children, and descendants, were masters of the **Great Dao**. They sought to show the world that the **Way** of longevity could be attained through study, not through supernatural feats alone.

The text states: *"Moreover, Laozi’s descendants performed unceasing sacrifices at **Qi**."* The scripture says:
*"The skilled builder does not cling; the skilled embrace does not abandon. Descendants continue sacrifices unceasingly—this is the text of the original *Chapter Fifty-Four*."*

Its meaning has already been elucidated in this chapter.

*"Ascending to **Yujing**"*—the *Scripture on Guiding the People* [《度人经》] says:
*"The **Yùluóxiāo Terrace**, the **Jade Mountain Upper Capital**, the **Supreme Beyond Supreme**, the **Great Luo Jade Purity**—vast and boundless, like the void, as if nonexistent yet existing. This is the dwelling of the **Upper Saints of the Three Purities** [三清上圣]. Mentioning the **Great Luo Jade Purity** implies the **Upper Purity** and **Supreme Purity** within it are known."*

Thus, it is said: *"Ascending to **Yujing**."*

Next, it states: *"**Zhuangzi**, beating his basin to send off his wife, then entered to serve the **Celestial Sovereign**."* The *Southern Flower Scripture* *Chapter on Perfect Joy* [《至乐篇》] says:
*"When **Zhuangzi’s** wife died, **Huizi** condoled him. **Zhuangzi** sat cross-legged, feet stretched out arrogantly, sawing wood with a song. **Huizi** said: ‘Living with someone, growing old together, and then dying—even without weeping, that is enough. Yet you beat your basin and sing—is this not excessive?’ **Zhuangzi** replied: ‘Not so. At her death, how could I not mourn? But considering her origin—she was never born. Not only was she never born, but she had no form. Not only no form, but no **qi**. She mingled with the indistinct and the indistinct, transforming into **qi**, **qi** transforming into form, form transforming into life. Now she transforms again into death—this is the cycle of spring, autumn, winter, and summer. People lie still in the great hall, taking Heaven and Earth as their dwelling. Yet I, clattering and wailing in pursuit of her, deemed myself unaligned with **Heaven’s Command** [命], so I stopped.’"*

It also says: *"Entering to serve the **Celestial Sovereign**."* According to the *New Record of the Dan Platform* [《丹台新录》]:
*"**Zhuangzi** ascended as **Grand Master of the Great Mystery** [太玄博士], a position of immortality."*

chunks.original_text: 故云入侍帝宸。 又题曰：皆为道之宗师者。 将使世人信其长生之可学，非神异而学不能及也。 是曰方外之教，有淳古之风焉者。 夫方内之教，论人伦之道，治世之法也。 方外之教，论玄古之风，出世之法也。 何则？ 《庄子大宗师篇》云：子桑户、孟子反、子琴张三人相与为友，莫然有间，而子桑户死，未葬。 孔子闻之，使子贡往待事焉。 或编曲，或鼓琴，相和而歌曰：嗟来桑户乎，嗟来桑户乎，而已反其真，而我犹为人猗於宜切。 子贡趋而进曰：敢问临尸而歌，礼乎？ 二人相视而笑曰：是恶知礼意。 子贡反，以告孔子曰：彼何人者邪，修行无有，而外其形骸，临尸而歌，颜色不变，无以命之，彼何人者邪。 孔子曰：彼游方之外者也。 丘游方之内者也。 外内不相及，而丘使汝往吊之，丘则陋矣。 彼方且与造物者为人，而游乎天地之一气，彼以生为附赘音缀。 县疣，以死为决音缓。 溃瘫，夫若然者，又恶知死生先后之所在。 夫方外之教，又岂止此一端而已。 盖举其大略而言也。

「Thus it is said: "Entering to serve the Celestial Sovereign." It is further inscribed: *"All are Dao’s Grand Masters."*

He intended to make the world believe that longevity could be cultivated through learning—not through divine or extraordinary means, but through study. This is the teaching of the **outer realm** [方外], which carries the **pure and ancient Daoist wind** [淳古之風].

Now, the teaching of the **inner realm** [方内] discusses the **Dao of human relations** [人倫之道] and the **methods of governance for the world** [治世之法]. The teaching of the **outer realm** [方外] expounds upon the **mysterious and ancient Daoist wind** [玄古之風] and the **methods of transcendence** [出世之法].

Why so? The *Zhuangzi: Grand Master* [《莊子·大宗師》] states:

The three friends—**Zi Sanghu** [子桑户], **Mengzi Fan** [孟孫反], and **Zi Qin Zhang** [子琴張]—lived together in harmony, without discord. When **Zi Sanghu** died and had not yet been buried, **Confucius** heard of it and sent **Zigong** [子貢] to attend to the funeral rites. Some plucked strings, others struck the **qin** [琴], and together they sang in harmony:

*"Alas, here comes Zi Sanghu! Alas, here comes Zi Sanghu!
Yet he has returned to his true nature,
And I still cling to human existence—ah, how fitting!"*

**Zigong** hurried forward and asked: *"May I inquire: to stand beside a corpse and sing—is this proper ritual?"*

The two men looked at each other and laughed: *"How could you possibly understand the meaning of ritual?"*

**Zigong** withdrew and reported to **Confucius**: *"What kind of men are they? They practice no cultivation, yet they abandon their physical forms. Standing beside the corpse, they sing, their complexions unchanged—there is no way to describe them. What kind of men are they?"*

**Confucius** replied: *"They dwell beyond the realm of the world’s conventions. I, however, dwell within the world’s conventions. The outer and inner realms do not intersect, yet I sent you to mourn them—how crude of me!"*

*"Those men are already becoming one with the Creator, wandering in the **one qi** of Heaven and Earth. To them, life is but a parasitic growth, a **wart** [附赘] or **canker** [音缀], and death is its removal, like **surgically excising a wart** [决疣] or **draining a boil** [溃瘫]. If they are like this, how could they know the order of death and life?"*

*"The teaching of the outer realm is by no means limited to this single example. It is merely a broad outline of its principles."*

chunks.original_text: 是故碧虚序云：论老庄虽有妻室子孙，然卒为大道之宗师，人天之教主者，盖由混迹人间，游心方外，力行大道之所致也。 欲俾世人知长生之可学，非神异而学不能及也。 故曰是为方外之教，有淳古之风焉。 道德真经藏室慕微闭题科文疏卷之四竟 道德真经藏室纂微开题科文疏卷之五 太霞老人薛致玄述 题曰：而历代尊崇，庙貌不绝，至唐乾封元年，高宗诏赠老君为玄元皇帝。 光宅元年，太后诏赠尹氏为先天太后，故为有唐圣祖焉。 疏曰：此第十五门明太上玄恩普被，圣德遐长，历代尊崇，庙貌不绝，故有唐尊为圣祖焉。 题曰历代尊崇，庙貌不绝者，爰自周、秦、汉、隋及唐、宋以来，莫不朝朝尊奉，代代钦崇，饰修宫宇，源源不绝，故长安终南之楼观，乃尹真人之故宅，太上传经之所也。 至周穆王时，贲音秘。 饰宫祠，访求幽逸之人，杜冲并真人之弟尹轨，俾主领观事，仍度道士七人，迄今八兴八废矣。 又亳州太清官者，太上降生之所也。 历代修崇，皆有碑记，故汉有蔡邕碑、边绍碑，隋有薛道衡碑，唐碑已讹缺不完，莫详孰氏所撰。 昔王希夷有诗云：双阙已讹唐故事，残碑犹有汉文章是也。 至宋有张商英碑，皆代代修崇之明验也。 又陕西凤翔府岐山之阳有启圣宫，当文王时，号燮邑子所居之地也。 又平阳府浮山县有天圣观，乃太上当唐高宗时，乘青鬃白骡显化之地也。 乃至蜀都之青羊官玉局观，秦州之柏林观，本号启灵宫，又有太霄官，崆峒山之问道宫，城父县之天静官，北邓山之上清宫，处处显化，朝朝尊崇，无有穷尽，不可具陈。 至有唐尊为圣祖者，当高宗乾封元年太岁丙寅二月二十八日，追上尊号曰玄元皇帝。 按《广圣义》解玄元皇帝四字云：夫玄者深也，妙也，亦云道也，天也。 言至道高妙不可言诠。 约妙与深，以玄为极，言深妙玄远以明道之体也。 故谓之玄。 夫元者初也，本也，祖也。 《尔雅》云肇祖元台伥落权舆始也。 言太上老君为大道之根源，万物之宗祖，处世出世之法，皆谓之本始，故谓之元。 夫皇者大也，谓大道也。 又曰道大曰皇。 《尚书序》云：三皇之书，谓之三坟，言大道也。 故曰皇。 夫帝者天也。 其德配天，次於道也。 又曰德大曰帝。 《书序》云：五帝之书谓之五典，言常道也。 道德兼称曰皇帝。 又云法道法天，谓之皇帝。 故曰玄元皇帝也。 至玄宗朝，又加圣祖二字，乃曰圣祖玄元皇帝焉。 古者称王不敢称帝，称帝不敢称皇，所以有三皇五帝三王之优劣也。 至秦始皇既以灭周一统天下，於是焚灭先代典籍，自我作古，将欲垂法后代，上探三皇之尊称，下取五帝之美号，两字兼称，号曰皇帝，仍欲以皇帝之称，自兹为始，故谓之始皇帝也。 故有唐既尊太上为圣祖，仍下诏追赠为圣祖玄元皇帝焉。 乃改谷阳县为真源县，当县宗姓特给复一年，用伸尊祖之意也。 至光宅元年，太后下诏追赠圣母尹氏尊号为先天太后，於太清宫之北一里立宫，号曰洞霄宫，左曰先天观，右曰广灵官，中曰洞霄宫，即圣母之故居也。 见有遗履坟存焉。 又至宋真宗朝，追上老君尊号曰太上混元上德皇帝。 太上二字，已具前释。 夫混元者，言太上生於混沌之先，长於亿劫之始，故曰混元也。

**Title:** Yet, across the dynasties, they were revered without ceasing. In the first year of *Tiānshòu* (695 CE), Emperor Gaozong posthumously conferred upon Laozi the title **Playen Emperor**. In the first year of *Guāngzhù* (684 CE), the Empress Dowager posthumously conferred upon Lady Yin the title **Primordial Empress**, thus making her the **Holy Ancestor of the Tang**.

**Commentary:** This is the fifteenth chapter, which clarifies that the **Playen Emperor’s** boundless virtue endures eternally, and across the dynasties, he was revered without ceasing. Thus, the Tang honored him as the **Holy Ancestor**.

**Title:** Those who were revered without ceasing across the dynasties—from the Zhou, Qin, Han, and Sui, down to the Tang and Song—each generation paid homage, each age venerated him, and the temples were continuously restored. Thus, the *Lóuguān* pavilions in the southern mountains of *Cháng’ān* were the former residence of the **True Person Yin**, where the **Playen One** transmitted the scriptures.

During the reign of King Mu of Zhou, the temples were adorned, and those who sought seclusion were summoned. Du Chong and the **True Person Yin’s** younger brother, Yin Guǐ, were appointed to oversee the observatory, and seven Daoist priests were ordained—this has since seen eight periods of flourishing and eight of decline.

The *Tàiqīng* Office in *Bózhōu* was the place of the **Playen One’s** birth. Across the dynasties, it was honored with inscriptions, including the *Cài Yōng* stele, the *Biàn Shào* stele, and the *Xuē Dàohéng* stele of the Sui. The Tang-era steles are now corrupted and incomplete, and it is unclear who composed them. As Wang Xīyí once wrote:

*"The twin gates stand in ruins, lost to Tang custom,
Yet the broken steles still bear Han’s refined prose."*

In the Song, there was the *Zhāng Shāngyīng* stele—clear evidence of their perpetual veneration.

In *Fèngxiàng Fǔ*, *Qíshān*’s southern slope stands the *Qǐshèng* Palace, said to be the residence of **Wénwáng’s** son, **Xièyì**.

In *Píngyáng Fǔ*, *Fúshān Xiàn*’s *Tiānshèng* Observatory was where, during the reign of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, the **Playen One** manifested in a green-muzzled white donkey.

Then there is the *Qīngyáng* Palace in *Chéngdū*, the *Yùjú* Observatory in *Qínzhōu*, originally called the *Qǐlíng* Palace, as well as the *Tàixiāo* Palace, the *Wèndào* Palace on *Kōngtóng Shān*, the *Tiānjìng* Palace in *Chéngfǔ Xiàn*, and the *Shàngqīng* Palace on *Běidēng Shān*—manifestations and veneration without end, too numerous to enumerate.

As for the Tang’s honorific of **Holy Ancestor**, it was in the first year of *Tiānshòu* (695 CE), on the twenty-eighth day of the second month, in the year of the *Bingyín* (1957 in the sexagenary cycle), that the title **Playen Emperor** was posthumously bestowed upon the **Playen One**.

According to the *Guāngshèngyì*, the four characters **Playen Emperor** are explained thus:

*"Playen" refers to depth, subtlety, and also the **Dao** and Heaven. It speaks of the **Dao**’s supreme, ineffable mystery—its profound and subtle essence, hence the term **Playen**.*

*"Yuan" means origin, root, and ancestor. The *Ēryǎ* states: "Zhào, zǔ, yuán, tái, yāngluò, quán yú, shǐ" (to begin, to found, to originate). It means the **Playen One** is the root of the **Dao** and the ancestor of all things. Whether in the world or beyond it, all laws stem from him—thus, he is called **Yuan**.*

*"Huáng" means great, referring to the **Dao** itself. It is also said, "The **Dao** is great, hence **Huáng**." The *Shàngshū Xù* states: "The books of the Three Sovereigns are called *Sānfén*, meaning the great **Dao**." Thus, it is **Huáng**.*

*"Dì" means Heaven. His virtue aligns with Heaven, second only to the **Dao**. It is also said, "Great virtue is called **Dì**." The *Shū Xù* states: "The books of the Five Emperors are called *Wǔdiǎn*, meaning the constant **Dao**." When both **Dao** and virtue are spoken of together, it is called **Huángdì**. It is also said, "To follow the **Dao** and align with Heaven is to be **Huángdì**." Thus, it is the **Playen Emperor**.*

In the reign of Emperor Xuānzong, the titles **Holy Ancestor** were added, making it **Holy Ancestor Playen Emperor**.

In ancient times, kings did not dare call themselves emperors, and emperors did not dare call themselves sovereigns—hence the distinction between the Three Sovereigns, Five Emperors, and Three Kings. When Qin Shǐhuáng unified the world and extinguished the Zhou, he burned the records of past dynasties, rewrote history, and sought to establish a precedent. He took the title of the Three Sovereigns above and the Five Emperors below, combining them into **Huángdì**, declaring himself the first of his kind—thus, **First Emperor**.

Therefore, the Tang, in honoring the **Playen One** as the **Holy Ancestor**, also issued a decree posthumously conferring the title **Holy Ancestor Playen Emperor**. The county of *Gǔyáng* was renamed *Zhēnyuán*, and the local Yin clan was granted a one-year tax exemption to honor their ancestral roots.

In the first year of *Guāngzhù* (684 CE), the Empress Dowager issued a decree posthumously conferring upon Lady Yin, the **Holy Mother**, the title **Primordial Empress**. To the north of the *Tàiqīng* Palace, one *lǐ* away, a palace was built, named *Dòngxiāo* Palace, with *Xiāntiān* Observatory to the left and *Guānglíng* Palace to the right. The central structure was the *Dòngxiāo* Palace, the **Holy Mother’s** former residence. Her burial mound and a surviving sandal were still present.

In the reign of Emperor Zhēnzōng of the Song, the **Playen One** was posthumously honored as **Playen Emperor of Supreme Primordial Virtue**.

The term **Playen** has already been explained. As for **Hùnyuán**, it speaks of the **Playen One** emerging before the chaos of *Hùntūn* and enduring at the dawn of countless *yàjié* (aeons). Thus, he is called **Hùnyuán**.

chunks.original_text: 上德者，谓太上每言功成不居，长而不宰，无德可称，故曰上德也。 皇帝二字已解于前，故曰太上混元上德皇帝。 仍改真源县为卫真县，即今之县名是也。 故云追赠老子为太上混元上德皇帝者以此也。 题曰：昔老子着书曰《道》《德》二篇，今曰老子《道德经》者，当是关尹受书之后标题云尔。 疏曰：此第十六门明后人受此二篇之后着经字之由尔。 夫此《道德经》者，厥初太上传授尹君真人止云《道》《德》二篇，殊无经字，亦无八十一章之数。 夫经者，常也，言此《道》《德》二篇之义为万世常行不易之典也。 是知后人受书之后尊此二篇，故升之为经也。 今详题文所论此经之一字，当是关尹受书之后标题云尔。 亦如儒教五经《易》、《尚书》、《毛诗》、《春秋》、《礼记》之类，厥初止是逐书之本题，亦是后之学者尊师重书之礼，故升之为五经也。 又如庄、列、文、么几四子，本为子书，至有唐玄宗朝，敬上玄虚，旌崇道典，故以《庄子》为《南华真经》，《列子》 为《 冲虚至德真经》 、《文子》为《通玄真经》，《亢仓子》为《洞灵真经》，亦此义也。 况我太上老君演道德之根源，为万教之宗祖，后之学者，尊以为经，不亦可乎。 又河上公分上下二经为八十一章焉。 题曰：夫道者，官然难言，有物混成，故强名日道。 以其通生万物，故训曰通也。 又道蹈也。 况道路之道，使人佩服其言而履行之也。 故道者德之钦也。 有道则必有德。 德，得也。 内得於心，外得於物，得而不丧也，故物得以生，谓之德。 有德则必全道。 道德相须而不相离，故曰道德也。 疏曰：此第十七门正明道德训释之义也。 题云夫道宝然难言哉，有物混成，强名日道者。 宝然，深奥之义也。 夫道无形无影无色无声，非神口之所能辩，至深至奥而不可以言诠也。 故庄子曰：夫道宝然难言哉者，已具本经首章详载。 又本经云道者万物之奥。 又《度人经》云是谓玄奥难可寻，详孟子养浩然之气曰难言也。 庄子又曰：道不可言，言而非也，皆此义也。 故云夫道者窅然难言哉。 又题曰有物混成，强名曰道者。 此本经第二十五章之文也。 已具本章消释，今不复云。 又题云道者通也，以通生万物为义，故训通也。 又曰道蹈也。 况道路之道，使人佩服其言而履行之也。 又解曰道，导也。 导，引也。 所谓导迷令悟，引凡入圣之谓也。 《自然经》云：导末归本者是也。 本即真性也，末即妄情也。 所以导引妄情复於真性也。 故曰道者导也。 又《庄子庚桑楚篇》云：道者德之钦也。 钦，敬也。 言德之所可尊敬者，道也。 题曰有道则必有德。 德，得也。 内得於心，外得於物，使道在於我而不丧也。 物得以生，谓之德。 凡物之生，必始资於道气，然后乃生，既生而养育之，则赖於德也。 故经云道生之，德畜之，是也。 又解云：德者成也。 所以济度众生，令成於无极之道果，故曰德。 题曰有德则必全道，道德相须而不相离，故曰道德也。 夫道者，德之体也。 德者，道之用之。 用以体立，体以用明，譬如草木之有根本﹑花果也。 根本者，草木之体也。 花果者，草木之用也。 是知花之与果皆从根本中来。 若非根本，则花之与果从何而生。

The **Playen Emperor of Supreme Primordial Virtue** thus holds the title **"Supreme Virtue"**—for the **Playen One** always speaks of achieving success without claiming credit, enduring without dominating, and possessing no virtue that could be named, hence he is called **"Supreme Virtue."**

The terms *Emperor* and *Playen* have already been explained earlier, thus the full title is **Playen Emperor of Supreme Primordial Virtue**. Moreover, the county of *Zhēn Yuán* was renamed *Wèi Zhēn*, which remains its present name. Hence, it is said that the posthumous honor bestowed upon Laozi as **Playen Emperor of Supreme Primordial Virtue** stems from this.

The title reads: *"In ancient times, the Old Master composed two treatises, one called* **Dao** *and the other* **De***. Now it is known as the* **Laozi’s Dao De Jing***, likely because after Master Guan Yin received the teachings, he designated them with this title."*

The commentary states: *"This is the sixteenth section, clarifying the origin of the term* **Jing** *(Scripture) *after the* **Holy Mother** *received these two treatises."*

Indeed, the **Dao De Jing** originally consisted only of the two treatises on **Dao** and **De**, with no mention of *Jing* and no count of eighty-one chapters. The term **Jing** means "constant"—that is, the teachings of **Dao** and **De** are eternal principles that must be followed by all ages without alteration. Thus, knowing that the **Holy Mother** later revered these two treatises, they were elevated to the status of **Jing**. The term *Jing* in the title of this work is likewise applied after Master Guan Yin received the teachings.

This is akin to the Confucian Five Classics—*Yì* (Changes), *Shàngshū* (Book of Documents), *Máo Shī* (Odes), *Chūnqiū* (Spring and Autumn Annals), and *Lǐjì* (Record of Rites)—which initially bore only their original names. Later scholars, in their respect for the teachers and veneration of the texts, elevated them to the status of the Five Classics.

Again, the four masters—Zhuangzi, Liezi, Wenzi, and Kangcangzi—originally composed works simply titled *Zhuangzi*, *Liezi*, *Wenzi*, and *Kangcangzi*. During the reign of Emperor Xuánzōng of the Tang, who revered the **Playen Way** and honored Daoist teachings, their works were renamed as follows: *Zhuangzi* became the *Nánhuá Zhēnxīng Jing* (South Flower Scripture of True Mystery), *Liezi* became the *Chōngxū Zhìdé Zhēnxīng Jing* (Scripture of True Virtue and Supreme Mystery), *Wenzi* became the *Tōngxuán Zhēnxīng Jing* (Scripture of True Perfection), and *Kāngcāngzi* became the *Dònglíng Zhēnxīng Jing* (Scripture of True Mysterious Essence). This is of the same meaning.

Moreover, our **Playen Old Master** expounds the roots of **Dao** and **De**, serving as the progenitor of all teachings. Later scholars, in their reverence, elevate these works to the status of **Jing**. Is this not entirely appropriate?

Master Heshang further divided the **Upper** and **Lower Jing** into eighty-one chapters.

The title states: *"**Dao** is indeed profound and difficult to speak of. There exists a formless substance, hence it is named* **Dao** *with force. Since it permeates all things, it is called* **Tōng** *(Permeating). Again,* **Dao** *is also* **Dào** *(to tread). As for the* **Dao** *of paths and roads, it is something that people revere and follow in practice. Hence,* **Dao** *is the awe-inspiring aspect of* **De** *(Virtue). Where there is* **Dao**, *there must be* **De**. *And* **De** *is* **Dé** *(to obtain). Obtaining within the heart and without in things, it is something that cannot be lost, hence all things obtain life through it—this is* **De***. Where there is* **De**, *there must be complete* **Dao**. *Since* **Dao** *and* **De** *are mutually dependent yet inseparable, they are called* **Dao De** *together."*

The commentary states: *"This is the seventeenth section, which elucidates the meaning of* **Dao De** *and its explanations."*

The title further states: *"**Dao** is indeed profound and difficult to speak of. There exists a formless substance, hence it is named* **Dao** *with force."* The profound and mysterious meaning is explained thus: **Dao** has no form, no shadow, no color, no sound. It cannot be distinguished by the divine mouth, being too profound and mysterious to be articulated. Hence, Zhuangzi says: *"**Dao** is indeed profound and difficult to speak of,"* which is already detailed in the first chapter of this **Jing**.

Again, this **Jing** states: *"**Dao** is the profound mystery of all things."* And the *Dù Rén Jing* (Scripture of Transforming People) states: *"This is called the profound mystery that is difficult to seek."* This is also akin to Mencius’ teaching of nurturing the *Hàorán* **Qi** (the expansive and boundless **Qi**), which he calls difficult to speak of. Zhuangzi also says: *"**Dao** cannot be spoken of; if spoken of, it is not accurate."* This is the same meaning.

Hence, it is said that **Dao** is indeed profound and difficult to speak of.

Again, the title states: *"There exists a formless substance, hence it is named* **Dao** *with force."* This is the text from the twenty-fifth chapter of this **Jing**, which has already been explained in this section and will not be repeated.

Again, the title states: *"**Dao** is also* **Tōng** *(Permeating), since it permeates all things."* Hence, it is called *Tōng* (Permeating).

Again, it says: *"**Dao** is also* **Dào** *(to tread)."* As for the **Dao** of paths and roads, it is something that people revere and follow in practice. Another explanation states: **Dao** is guidance. Guidance means to lead. It refers to guiding the lost to enlightenment and leading the ordinary to the sacred.

The *Zìrán Jing* (Scripture of Nature) states: *"This is the guidance of the end back to the origin."* The origin is true nature, and the end is false emotions. Hence, **Dao** is the guidance of false emotions back to true nature. Therefore, it is said that **Dao** is guidance.

Zhuangzi’s *Gēngsāng Pǔ* (Chapter of Geng Sang Pu) states: *"**Dao** is the awe-inspiring aspect of* **De** *(Virtue)."* Awe-inspiring means reverence. It states that what can be revered in **De** is **Dao**.

The title states: *"Where there is* **Dao**, *there must be* **De***."* **De** is obtaining. Obtaining **Dao** within oneself and applying it to all things, it is something that cannot be lost. All things obtain life through it—this is **De**.

The general principle is that all things must first rely on **Dao Qi** (the **Qi** of **Dao**) to exist, then nurtured and sustained by **De**. Hence, the **Jing** states: *"**Dao** gives birth to it;* **De** *nourishes it."* This is the case.

Another explanation states: **De** is completion. It is the means by which all beings are guided to attain the fruit of the boundless **Dao**. Hence, it is called **De**.

The title states: *"Where there is* **De**, *there must be complete* **Dao***. Since* **Dao** *and* **De** *are mutually dependent yet inseparable, they are called* **Dao De** *together."*

**Dao** is the essence of **De**, and **De** is the manifestation of **Dao**. The essence establishes the foundation, and the manifestation clarifies the essence. This is like the roots and branches of plants and trees, where the roots and branches are the essence, and the flowers and fruits are the manifestation.

Thus, it is known that flowers and fruits all arise from the roots and branches. If there were no roots and branches, then how could flowers and fruits emerge?

chunks.original_text: 非花果，则根本妙用何由而显。 故知花果、根本乃草木之一体也。 喻如道德体用亦然。 夫根本妙用幽隐，而人所不则者也。 花之与果显明，而人所见者也。 然则见於不见，皆起於一体，亦如道无形色杳冥而人所不见者也。 德有作用显着，而人所见者也。 然而无之与有、隐之与显，亦一体也明矣。 按《广圣义》云：道德一体而具二，义，一而不一，二而不二，二而不二，由一故二，一而不一，由二故一，不可言有体无体，亦不可言有用无用，盖是无体为体，体而无体，无用为用，用而无用。 寻其体也，离空离有，非阴非阳，视听不得，搏触莫辨。 寻其用也，能权能实，可左可右，以小容大，以大容小。 体既无穷，用亦莫尽，是知道德体用之义，固不可思而议之也。 斯可体用两忘，有无双遣，方至此理也。 故题文所论有德则必全道，道德相须而不相离，故曰道德也。 是故司马迁云：为阴阳者繁而致惑，为儒者博而多虑，为墨者苦而伤性，为名者华而少实，为法者酷而薄恩，唯老氏之教，称为大道焉。 清虚无为，使精神专一，动合无形，赡足万物。 其为术也，与时迁移，应物变化，无所不宜。 旨约而易操，事少而功多，其实易行，其辞易知，以虚无为本，以因循为用。 无成势，无常形，故能究万物之情。 不为物先，不为物后，故能为万物之主。 是以先黄老而后六经，独叹道家为清尚焉。 故曰九经浩浩，不及二篇之约也。 题曰：经者，常也，法也。 言其理有常可法，如九经可法之义也。 又经者，书之尊称也。 今言《道经》上《德经》下者，上篇之首取其道可道非常道，下篇之首取其上德不德是以有德而题之也。 后之说者，故随文生义。 言道非德，无以显。 德非道，无以明。 道无为无形，故居化物之先。 德有用有为，故在生物之后。 道居先，故处上。 德居后，故处下。 又道衰而有德，德衰而有五常，是明道德为众行之先、五常之本。 故《道经》居先，《德经》次之。 上下二卷，法两仪之生育，八十一章，象太阳之极数。 是以上经明道以法天，下经明德以法地，而天数奇，故上经三十七章。 地数偶，故下经四十四章。 然则起自先贤，且仍旧贯。 疏曰：此第十八门正明经训之义，及上下二经八十一章取法之旨。 就此门中，又分为二。 其一正明经训之义。 其二明上下二经八十一章取法之旨。 一日正明经训之义者，题曰经者，常也，法也。 言其理有常可法也。 如九经可法之义也。 又经者，书之尊称也。 按《广圣义》中所解，经者诸家解释凡有四义：一由、二径、三法、四常也。 一由者，言三世天尊，十方圣众，皆由经教证圣成真也。 二径者，言开通道理，导达众生，为学者之津梁，登真之径路也。 三法者，言真趣玄妙，至理精微，可以为群生之楷苦骇切模，众圣之法式也。 四常者，言妙理深远，冥寂玄通，万代百王，不刊之典也。 具此四义，总称为经，其或结气成文，凝云作篆，字方一丈，八角垂芒。 或玉字琼章，龙书凤扎，劫初降世，劫末归天。 或刊玉钨金，竹木缣纸，流传演化，篆隶随时。 虽赢妙不同，皆玄圣真诀，为治病之良药，乃出世之妙门也。 假使代变时移，金消石化，而我《道德真经》 垂世立教，常布於人天，万劫长存，以为修身治世之达道，证果登真之法式，故曰经也。
chunks.translated_text:
Without flowers and fruit, how could the wondrous functions of the roots and branches ever be revealed?

Thus, it is known that flowers and fruit, roots and branches—all are but one body of the plant.

This is like the **Dao** and **De** in their essence and function.

The roots and branches, with their wondrous functions, are subtle and hidden, yet what people do not follow.

Flowers and fruit are manifest and clear, yet what people see.

Yet what is seen and unseen all arise from one body—just as the **Dao** is formless, distant, and unseen by people.

**De** has actions and manifestations, yet what people see.

However, the nonexistent and the existent, the hidden and the manifest—all are one body, now made clear.

According to the *Guang Sheng Yi* [Extensive Explanation of Sacred Meaning], it states:

**"Dao De** is one yet possesses two aspects—its meaning is one yet not one, two yet not two. Two yet not two, because of one; one yet not one, because of two. It cannot be said there is a body without body, nor can it be said there is function without function. Rather, it is that which has no body is the body, the body without body; that which has no function is the function, the function without function.

To seek its essence: beyond emptiness and being, neither yin nor yang, unseen by sight or hearing, untouchable and indistinguishable.

To seek its function: capable of both expedient and reality, adaptable to left or right, containing the small within the great, the great within the small.

Its essence is boundless, its function inexhaustible—thus, the meaning of **Dao De**’s essence and function is indeed beyond thought and discussion.

Only when one transcends essence and function, discards both existence and nonexistence, does one reach this truth.

Thus, the title states: *"Where there is* **De**, *there must be complete* **Dao***. Since* **Dao** *and* **De** *are mutually dependent yet inseparable, they are called* **Dao De** *together."*

Hence, Sima Qian said:

*"Those who follow the yin-yang school are excessive and cause confusion; those who follow Confucianism are broad but prone to overthinking; those who follow Mohism are harsh and harm nature; those who pursue fame are superficial and lack substance; those who uphold legalism are cruel and unkind. Only the teachings of Laozi are called the Great **Dao**—

Clear and empty, taking no action, yet concentrating the spirit,
Moving in harmony with the formless, suffusing all things.

Its methods adapt to changing times, responding to transformations in all things, fitting every circumstance.

Its principles are concise yet easy to practice, its actions few yet its results great.
Its practice is simple, its words easy to understand—
Rooted in emptiness and nonexistence, employing natural progression as its function.

Without fixed form or constant shape, it thus thoroughly understands the nature of all things.

Neither leading nor following things, it thus becomes the sovereign of all things.

Therefore, it precedes the Yellow Old [classics] and follows the Six Classics, uniquely praising Daoism for its purity and reverence.

Thus, it is said: The vastness of the Nine Classics does not compare to the brevity of the Two Chapters [of the *Dao De Jing*]."*

The title states:

*"Jing* [Classic] refers to what is constant and what is law—
Speaking of principles that are constant and can be emulated, as in the meaning of the Nine Classics being something to emulate.

Again, *jing* is the honored term for scripture.
Now, the *Dao Jing* [Classic of the **Dao**] is above, the *De Jing* [Classic of **De**] below—
The first line of the upper chapter takes its title from *‘The **Dao** that can be spoken of is not the eternal **Dao**,’*
The first line of the lower chapter takes its title from *‘Highest **De** is without **De**, thus it is called **De**.’*
Later commentators, therefore, follow the text to generate meaning.

Speaking of **Dao** without **De**, it cannot be revealed.
Speaking of **De** without **Dao**, it cannot be clarified.
The **Dao** is without action and form, thus it precedes the transformation of things.
**De** has function and action, thus it follows the generation of things.
The **Dao** precedes, hence it is placed above.
**De** follows, hence it is placed below.

Again, when the **Dao** declines, **De** arises; when **De** declines, the Five Constants emerge—
This makes clear that **Dao De** is the foundation of all practices and the source of the Five Constants.

Thus, the *Dao Jing* comes first, the *De Jing* follows.
The two volumes together symbolize the generation of the two principles [yin-yang],
And the eighty-one chapters represent the extreme number of the sun.

Therefore, the upper chapter elucidates the **Dao** by emulating Heaven,
The lower chapter elucidates **De** by emulating Earth—
Heaven’s number is odd, hence the upper chapter has thirty-seven sections.
Earth’s number is even, hence the lower chapter has forty-four sections.

Thus, it begins with ancient sages and continues the ancient tradition.

The commentary states:
*This is the eighteenth gate, properly clarifying the meaning of the term ‘jing’ and the intent behind the eighty-one chapters of the upper and lower classics.*

Within this gate, there are two divisions:
The first properly clarifies the meaning of the term ‘jing.’
The second elucidates the intent behind the eighty-one chapters of the upper and lower classics.

First, properly clarifying the meaning of the term ‘jing’:
The title states: *"Jing* refers to what is constant and what is law—
Speaking of principles that are constant and can be emulated, as in the meaning of the Nine Classics being something to emulate.

Again, *jing* is the honored term for scripture.
According to the explanations in the *Guang Sheng Yi*, the term *jing* has four conventional interpretations:
One, *‘by’*—meaning the Three Worlds’ Celestial Sovereigns and the ten-directional saints all attain enlightenment and true reality through the teachings of the *jing*.
Two, *‘path’*—meaning it opens and communicates principles, guiding sentient beings as a bridge for scholars and a path to true reality.
Three, *‘law’*—meaning it reveals profound truths and subtle principles, serving as a model for all beings and a standard for all saints.
Four, *‘constant’*—meaning its profound principles are distant and silent, a timeless standard for all ages and rulers.

Possessing these four meanings, it is collectively called *jing*.
Sometimes, it is formed by condensed *qi* and written in cloud-like script, with characters a *zhang* [ten feet] wide, eight-cornered with drooping rays.
Sometimes, it is inscribed in jade letters or jade plates, with dragon-script and phoenix-bindings, descending at the beginning of a kalpa and returning to Heaven at its end.
Sometimes, it is engraved on jade or gold, written on bamboo, wood, silk, or paper, transmitted and transformed across time, with seals and clerical scripts adapting to the era.

Though their marvels differ, all are sacred and true secrets—
Excellent remedies for healing ailments, wondrous gates to transcendence.

Even if ages change and metals decay into stone, our *Dao De Jing* [True Classic of **Dao De**] remains in the world, eternally benefiting humans and celestial beings, enduring for countless kalpas as the supreme path for self-cultivation and governance, the standard for attaining fruit and true reality.

Thus, it is called *jing*."

chunks.original_text: 其二明上下二经及八十一章取法之旨者。 题曰《道经》上《德经》下云云，起自先贤，仍且旧贯者，题文已明，不必详解。 又观唐明皇疏序云：而经分上下者，先明道而德次之，然体用之名可散，而体用之实不可散也。 真实凝然之谓体，谓妙体也。 应变随机之谓用，谓妙用也。 故经云同出而异名，同谓之玄。 语其出则分而为二，咨其同则混而为一，故曰可散而不可散也。 则上经曰是谓玄德。 又曰孔德之容。 又曰德者同於德。 又曰常德不离。 故云道资於德。 下经曰失道而后德。 又曰反者道之动。 又曰道生一。 又曰大道甚夷。 故云德宗於道。 是其体用互陈，递明精要，不必定名於上下也。 题曰：此经以重玄为宗，自然为体，道德为用。 其要在乎治身治国。 治国则我无为而民自化，我无欲而民自朴。 治身则寒其兑，闭其门，谷神不死，少私寡欲。 此其要旨，可得而言也。 若夫视之不见，听之不闻，玄之又玄，众妙之门，殆不可得而言传也。 故游其廊庑者，自以谓升堂睹奥，及其研精覃思，然后於道，知其秋毫之端，万分未得处一焉。 疏曰：此第十九门明《道》、《德》二经之宗本，治国治身之大旨，以遗后学尔。 就此门中，又分为二。 其一明道德之宗本。 其二明治国治身之大旨。 其一明道德之宗本者。 题曰此经以重玄为宗，自然为体，道德为用。 夫重玄为宗者，经云同谓之玄，玄之又玄，众妙之门。 又云损之又损，以至於无为是也。 自然为体者，经云百姓皆谓我自然。 又云人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然是也。 道德为用者，经云道冲而用之。 又云反者道之动，弱者道之甩。 又云大盈若冲，其用不穷是也。 此其大旨也。 逐文之义，各具本章消释，今不复云。 《广圣义》 云：宗趣旨归者，言此《道德真经》包含众义，指归意趣，各有君宗。 且夫河上公、严君平等，皆明治国之道。 松灵仙人、魏代孙登、梁朝陶隐居、南齐顾欢等，皆明治身之道。 符坚时僧罗什、后赵时僧佛图澄、梁武帝时道士窦略等，皆明事理因果之道。 梁朝道士孟智周、臧玄静、陈朝道士朱练女救切、隋朝道士刘进喜、唐朝道士成玄英、蔡子晃、黄玄颐、李荣、车玄弼、张慧超、黎元兴等，皆明重玄之道。 何晏、锺会、杜元凯、王辅嗣、羊祜、卢氏、刘仁会等，皆明虚极无为治家治国之道。 此明注解之人，意趣俱各不同。 又诸家禀学立宗，亦各不同。 严君平以玄虚为宗。 顾欢以无为为宗。 孟智周、臧玄静以道德为宗。 梁武帝以非有非无为宗。 孙登以重玄为宗。 宗指之中，孙氏为妙。 夫此碧虚真人纂微者，亦以重玄为宗，自然为体，道德为用。 修之国则无为无事，自致太平。 修之家则六亲和睦，万祸不侵。 修之身则抱一守中，自登道果。 得之者排空蹑景，久视长生。 失之者祸身及家，残龄促寿。 在乎上士勤人，守之抱之，常为法式也。 其二明治国治身之大旨。 题曰：其要在乎治身治国云云，万分未得处一焉者。 以上题文，皆以本经为证，各於逐章下消释，今不复云。 且据唐《开元御疏序》云：夫《道》《德》二经，其要在理身理国。 理国则绝矜尚弃华薄，以无为不言为教。 理身则见素抱朴少私寡欲，以虚心实腹为务。
chunks.translated_text:
The second part elucidates the essence of the **Upper Dao Classic** and **Lower De Classic**, as well as the eighty-one chapters.

It is titled *The Dao Classic* above and *The De Classic* below—so it is said—originating from ancient sages, yet still following the old traditions. The title is already clear, and no further explanation is needed.

Again, observing the preface of the Tang Emperor Minghuang, it states: Though the **Classic** is divided into two parts, the **Dao** is first and **De** follows, yet the names of *body* (体 *tǐ*) and *function* (用 *yòng*) may be scattered, but their essence cannot be scattered. The true and solid essence is called *body*—that is, the **Mysterious Body**. The adaptable and responsive function is called *function*—that is, the **Mysterious Function**. Hence, the **Classic** speaks of *same origin, different names*, and *same essence, called Mysterious*. When speaking of their origin, they are divided into two; when speaking of their unity, they merge into one. Thus, it is said: *Names may be scattered, but essence cannot be scattered*.

Therefore, the **Upper Dao Classic** says: *"This is called Mysterious Virtue"* (是谓玄德 *shì wèi xuán dé*).
Again: *"The form of boundless virtue"* (孔德之容 *kǒng dé zhī róng*).
Again: *"Virtue is in accord with the Way"* (德者同於道 *dé zhě tóng yú dào*).
Again: *"The abiding virtue never departs"* (常德不离 *cháng dé bù lí*).
Hence, it is said: *The Way relies on virtue*.

The **Lower De Classic** says: *"Only after losing the Way do we speak of virtue"* (失道而后德 *shī dào ér hòu dé*).
Again: *"Reversion is the movement of the Way"* (反者道之动 *fǎn zhě dào zhī dòng*).
Again: *"The Way generates unity"* (道生一 *dào shēng yī*).
Again: *"The Great Way is most smooth"* (大道甚夷 *dà dào shèn yí*).
Hence, it is said: *Virtue originates from the Way*.

Thus, the **Classic** presents *body* and *function* in alternating exposition, revealing the core essence without rigidly distinguishing them by their titles.

It is titled: *This Classic takes **Double Mysterious** as its core, **Nature** as its body, and **Dao De** as its function*. Its essence lies in governing the self and the realm. To govern the realm, one must *do nothing while the people transform themselves*, and *desire nothing while the people return to simplicity*. To govern the self, one must *chill the **Jue** [mouth/joy] and close the **Men** [gates]*, so that the *Spirit of the Grain* (谷神 *gǔ shén*) does not perish, and *private desires are few while cravings are scarce*. These are its core principles, which may be spoken of.

But the **Mysterious** that is *seen but not seen, heard but not heard*—the **Mysterious** beyond the **Mysterious**, the **Gate of All Marvels**—is perhaps beyond what can be spoken or transmitted. Those who wander its halls and courtyards claim to have ascended the hall and glimpsed its depths, but only when they delve deeply and ponder with precision do they, in the Dao, know its *fine tip of an autumn hair* (秋毫之端 *qiū háo zhī duān*), yet still grasp but a fraction of its whole. The preface says: *This is the nineteenth gate, revealing the core principles of the **Dao** and **De** Classics, the great essence of governing the realm and the self, left for later generations to inherit*. Within this gate, there are two further divisions. The first elucidates the core principles of **Dao De**. The second reveals the great essence of governing the realm and the self.

The first, which elucidates the core principles of **Dao De**, is titled: *This Classic takes **Double Mysterious** as its core, **Nature** as its body, and **Dao De** as its function*. **Double Mysterious** as the core is evidenced by the **Classic**’s words: *"All called Mysterious"* (同谓之玄 *tóng wèi zhī xuán*), *"the **Mysterious** beyond the **Mysterious**, the **Gate of All Marvels**"* (玄之又玄，众妙之门 *xuán zhī yòu xuán, zhòng miào zhī mén*). Again: *"Reduce it again, reduce it again, until reaching **Do-Nothing***"* (损之又损，以至於无为 *sǔn zhī yòu sǔn, yǐ zhì yú wúwéi*). **Nature** as the *body* is evidenced by the **Classic**’s words: *"All the people say I am **Nature**"* (百姓皆谓我自然 *bǎi xiànng jiē wèi wǒ zìrán*). Again: *"Humans follow Earth, Earth follows Heaven, Heaven follows the Way, the Way follows **Nature**"* (人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然 *rén fǎ dì, dì fǎ tiān, tiān fǎ dào, dào fǎ zìrán*). **Dao De** as the *function* is evidenced by the **Classic**’s words: *"The Way is **Surging** yet its **Function** is applied"* (道冲而用之 *dào chōng ér yòng zhī*). Again: *"Reversion is the movement of the Way"* (反者道之动 *fǎn zhě dào zhī dòng*), *"The yielding is the **Way’s** withdrawal"* (弱者道之甩 *ruò zhě dào zhī shuǎi*). Again: *"Great fullness seems **Surging**—its **Function** is inexhaustible"* (大盈若冲，其用不穷 *dà yíng ruò chōng, qí yòng bù qióng). These are its great principles.

The meanings of each phrase are individually clarified in their respective chapters, and I shall not repeat them here.

The *Guangsheng Yi* [Comprehensive Sacred Meaning] says: *The core and its tendency are unified*—that is, this **True Classic of Dao De** encompasses all meanings, pointing to their intent and purpose, each with its own masterful principle. Moreover, the scholars such as **He Shang Gong** [Riverbank Master], **Yan Junping** [Sage of Strictness], all expounded on the **Way** of governing the realm. The **Songling Immortal**, **Sun Deng** of the Wei Dynasty, **Tao Yuanming** [Hidden Residence Sage] of the Liang Dynasty, **Gu Huan** of the Southern Qi, all expounded on the **Way** of governing the self. The monks **Luo Shi** in the time of **Fu Jian**, **Futuo Cheng** in the time of the **Hou Zhao**, and **Duo Lue** in the reign of **Liang Wu Emperor**, all expounded on the **Way** of matters, principles, and cause-and-effect. The Daoists **Meng Zhizhou**, **Zang Xuanjing**, **Zhu Lian** of the Chen Dynasty, **Liu Jinxi** of the Sui Dynasty, **Cheng Xuaneng**, **Cai Zihuang**, **Huang Xuan’ao**, **Li Rong**, **Che Xuanbi**, **Zhang Huichao**, and **Li Yuanxing** of the Tang Dynasty, all expounded on the **Way** of **Double Mysterious**. **He Yan**, **Zhong Hui**, **Du Yuankai**, **Wang Fusi**, **Yang Fu**, **Lu Shi**, and **Liu Renhui**, all expounded on the **Way** of **Do-Nothing** and **Void Extremity** for governing the family and the realm.

These scholars, in their interpretations and expositions, each have their own distinct tendencies. Moreover, each school’s reception of learning and establishment of doctrine also differs. **Yan Junping** took *Mysterious and Void* as his core. **Gu Huan** took *Do-Nothing* as his core. **Meng Zhizhou** and **Zang Xuanjing** took *Dao De* as their core. **Liang Wu Emperor** took *Neither Existence nor Non-Existence* as his core. **Sun Deng** took **Double Mysterious** as his core. Among these doctrines, **Sun Deng’s** is the most profound.

The **True Person of Azure Emptiness** [Laozi], who compiled these subtle teachings, also took **Double Mysterious** as his core, **Nature** as his *body*, and **Dao De** as his *function*. When practiced in the realm, it leads to *Do-Nothing and no affairs*, naturally attaining **Great Peace**. When practiced in the family, it brings *harmony among the six relations*, and *no calamities intrude*. When practiced in the self, it means *embracing unity and guarding the center*, naturally ascending to the **Way’s** fruition. Those who attain it *soar through the void and tread upon the luminous*, gazing long and living forever. Those who lose it suffer *calamity upon the self and the family*, with *shortened lifespan and hastened death*. It depends on the **Upper Sage** [superior person] who is diligent, guarding and embracing it, always as the standard model.

The second part, which reveals the great essence of governing the realm and the self—titled *Its essence lies in governing the self and the realm*—concerns the *fine tip of an autumn hair* that is but a fraction of the whole. The above titles are all verified by this **Classic** itself, with their meanings clarified in the respective chapters below. I shall not repeat them here.

Furthermore, according to the *Tang **Kaiyuan Imperial Commentary**’s preface*, it states: *The **Dao** and **De** Classics, their essence lies in governing the self and the realm*. To govern the realm is to *abolish arrogance and discard ornamentation*, practicing *Do-Nothing and saying nothing* as the teaching. To govern the self is to *manifest simplicity and embrace purity*, with *few private desires and scarce cravings*, striving for *a void heart and a substance-filled belly*.

chunks.original_text: 此其要旨可得而言也。 及乎穷理尽性？ 闭绿息想，处实行权，坐忘遗照，损之又损，玄之又玄，殆不可得而言传者也。 何谓穷理尽性？ 按《广圣义》云：穷理者穷极万物深妙之理。 尽性者究尽群生所禀之性。 物理既穷，生性亦尽，然后以至於命也。 闭绿息想者，随境生欲谓之绿，因心系念谓之想。 就此门中，分为四别。 一者意随善境而生善欲，谓之善绿。 二者意随恶境而生恶欲，谓之恶绿。 三者心系善念，谓之善想。 四者心系恶念，谓之恶想。 此四者虽同因境所起，分为善恶。 夫初修道者，既闭恶绿，又息恶想，以降其心，心澄气定，想念正真，稍入道分，善绿善想，亦复忘之。 然后穷达妙理，了尽真性，绿想俱忘，乃可得道。 故日穷理尽性，闭绿息想也。 处实行权者，《广圣义》 云：实者真谛，玄妙幽微，所谓妙本之道，大乘之趣也。 权者因事制宜，随时立教，谓中乘小乘之道，以诱迷悮者也。 迷悮一作开悟。 亦犹治身治国者，先资权教，后入大道，故云处实行权也。 坐忘遗照者，《广圣义》云：坐忘者，《庄子大宗师》云：禀肢体，黜聪明，离形去智，同於大通，谓之坐忘。 遗照者，至道玄微，不可以言诠，但可以心照，既因心照而得悟，其照亦忘，故曰遗照。 此皆大乘之道也。 损之又损，玄之又玄者。

The essential meaning here may be spoken of thus:

When it comes to exhausting principle and fulfilling nature—
to close off desires and still thoughts,
to dwell in the true and practice expedient means,
to sit in forgetfulness and abandon illumination—
to diminish again and again, to make it ever more profound—
these are matters so subtle they can scarcely be spoken of or transmitted.

What is meant by exhausting principle and fulfilling nature?
According to the *Guangsheng Yi*:
Exhausting principle means penetrating to the deepest, most subtle truths of all things.
Fulfilling nature means exhausting the inherent nature bestowed upon all beings.
When the principles of things are fully exhausted and the natures of beings are fully realized,
then one attains the ultimate in life’s purpose.

Closing off desires and stilling thoughts:
When the mind follows a scene and gives rise to craving, it is called *desire* (*lǜ*).
When the heart clings to thoughts and fixates, it is called *thought* (*xiǎng*).
Within this teaching, these are divided into four categories:
The first is when the mind follows a virtuous scene and gives rise to virtuous craving—this is called *virtuous desire*.
The second is when the mind follows a wicked scene and gives rise to wicked craving—this is called *wicked desire*.
The third is when the heart clings to virtuous thoughts—this is called *virtuous thought*.
The fourth is when the heart clings to wicked thoughts—this is called *wicked thought*.
Though all four arise from scenes, they are distinguished as virtuous or wicked.

For those who first cultivate the Dao,
after closing off wicked desires and stilling wicked thoughts,
they lower their minds, allowing them to settle—
their thoughts and reflections grow pure and true,
and they gradually enter the Dao’s path.
Even virtuous desires and virtuous thoughts are then forgotten.
Only then can one exhaust the subtle principles and realize true nature,
forgetting desires and thoughts alike,
and thus attain the Dao.
Hence it is said: *Exhaust principle, fulfill nature, close desires, still thoughts.*

To dwell in the true and practice expedient means:
According to the *Guangsheng Yi*,
the *true* refers to the profound, mysterious, and subtle essence—
the wondrous source of the Dao,
the path of the Great Vehicle.
The *expedient* means adapting to circumstances, establishing teachings according to time,
referring to the paths of the Middle and Lesser Vehicles,
used to guide those lost in delusion.
*Delusion* may also be read as *enlightenment*.

This is like governing the self and the realm—
first employing expedient teachings,
then entering the Great Dao.
Thus it is said: *Dwell in the true, practice expedient means.*

To sit in forgetfulness and abandon illumination:
According to the *Guangsheng Yi*,
*Sitting in forgetfulness* is as the *Zhuangzi*’s *Great Master* says:
Abandoning limbs, discarding perception,
severing form and discarding wisdom,
merging with the boundless—
this is called *sitting in forgetfulness*.
*Abandoning illumination* refers to the Dao’s profound mystery,
which cannot be articulated in words,
but only grasped through the mind’s illumination.
Once enlightenment comes through this illumination,
the illumination itself is forgotten—
hence *abandoning illumination*.
These are all teachings of the Great Vehicle.

To diminish again and again, to make it ever more profound—

To govern the self is to *manifest simplicity and embrace purity*, with *few private desires and scarce cravings*, striving for *a void heart and a substance-filled belly*.

chunks.original_text: 此皆本经之文，各於逐章消释。 是乃至微至妙之道，故云殆不可得而言传者也。 是故其教圆，其文约，其旨畅，其言迩。 游其廊厅者，自以为升堂睹奥，及其研精覃思，然后於道，知其秋毫之端，万分未得处一焉。 其教圆者，《广圣义》云：行有五教，分为五别。 一者挫锐解纷，和光同尘，初教也。 二者见素抱朴，虚心实腹，渐教也。 三者后其身而身先，外其身而身存，半教也。 四者损之又损，以至於无为，无为而无不为，满教也。 五者淡然常存，用之不勤，天地有终，大道无变，圆教也。 合此为教，五者俱备，万行总包，故曰其教圆。 圆者圆通一切，道无不在之谓也。 其旨约者，《广圣义》云：约者简省也。 不出二篇之文，五千余字，包罗万法，不亦约乎。 其文畅者，《广圣义》云：畅，通快也。 经云吾言甚易知，甚易行，不日畅乎。 其言迩者，《广圣义》云：迩，近也。 经云以身观身，以家观家，至於以天下观天下。 又云不出户知天下，不窥牖见天道，不日迩乎。 游其廊废者，自以为升堂睹奥者，《广圣义》云：廊者堂前之步廊也。 废者堂下也。 奥者室之内也。 西南隅谓之奥。 言世儒之士，习道之人，初睹此经，自谓穷　理尽性，而极於玄微尔。 及其研精覃思，然后知其於秋毫之端，万分未得其一焉者。 《广圣义》云：沈研钻考，其情运思，探道之奥，穷道之源，笺注诠疏，以求圣人之旨，其所得之　理愈少，圣人之意愈深。 言秋毫则细矣。 又云秋毫之端，则细之甚者也。 端，末也。 言於秋毫之末，万分之中未得其一，则少之至也。 故碧虚作开题，亦云其要在乎治身治国。 及其研精覃思，然后於道，知其秋毫　之端，万分未得处一焉耳。 题曰：辄依师授之旨，略纂昔贤之微，其如恍惚窅冥之理，在达者之自悟耳。 疏曰：此第二十门明我碧虚真人纂集训解之由，发明道德之义，以遗后学耳。 题曰辄依师授之旨，略纂昔贤之微者。 辄，专也。 乃碧虚自云，我今所解《道德》二经，皆是专辄依奉吾师鸿蒙张君真人传授之旨，仍纂集往昔贤达之士笺注此经，精微要妙之义，与经旨相合者，必明着本人氏号，取而证之，抑又讨论玄都宝藏、三洞四辅，群经子史，若稍有与此经义理相符合者，必探而录之，以为傍证，将使我太上老君《道德真经》重玄之理，坦然明白，俾诸后学，得其门而易入之也。 由是知我碧虚真人，上以弘阐犹龙玄微之教，下以开发后学蒙昧之心，庶使大道兴行，法轮常转，而无穷也。 不其伟欤。 又有集解四注《灵宝度人经》、《南华真经》章句解义，皆藏诸藏室，流传於人间，观其扶宗立教之诚，可谓至矣。 犹曰其如恍惚窅冥之理，在达者之自悟耳。 此又谦逊之辞也。
chunks.translated_text:
All this is the text of the original scripture, to be elucidated chapter by chapter.

This is the most subtle and wondrous of the Dao,
hence it is said: *Almost impossible to obtain and speak of, yet passed down.*

Thus its teachings are **comprehensive** (*yuan*), its text **concise** (*jue*), its meaning **unobstructed** (*chang*), and its words **profound** (*ni*).

Those who wander in its **corridors** (*lang*) and **vestibules** (*ting*)—
believe they have ascended the hall and glimpsed its mysteries (*ao*).
Yet when they delve deeply and ponder with earnest intent,
only then do they understand the Dao—
knowing its finest tip (*qiuhao zhī duan*), yet grasping but a fraction of its ten-thousandth part.

Its teachings are **comprehensive** (*yuan*)—
The *Guangsheng Yi* says:
The Way has five teachings, divided into five distinctions.
1. The first is to **blunt sharpness and resolve entanglements** (*cuo rui jie fen*), harmonizing light with dust—*the initial teaching*.
2. The second is to **embrace simplicity and preserve purity** (*jian su bao pu*), maintaining a **void heart** (*xu xin*) and **substantial belly** (*shi fu*)—*the gradual teaching*.
3. The third is to **let the body lag behind while it leads** (*hou qi shen er shen xian*), and **externalize the body while it remains** (*wai qi shen er shen cun*)—*the half-teaching*.
4. The fourth is to **diminish it again and again** (*sun zhi you sun*), until it reaches **non-action** (*wu wei*), where **non-action** is yet **nothing it does not accomplish** (*wu wei er wu bu wei*)—*the full teaching*.
5. The fifth is to **remain ever serene** (*dan ran chang cun*), using it without exertion (*bu qin*), for though heaven and earth may have an end, the **Great Dao remains unchanging** (*da dao wu bian*)—*the comprehensive teaching*.

Combined, these form the **teachings** (*jiao*).
All five are complete,
encompassing myriad practices (*wan xing zong bao*).
Hence it is said: *Its teachings are comprehensive*.
**Comprehensive** (*yuan*) means **penetrating all things** (*tong yi qie*), for the Dao is nowhere absent.

Its meaning is **concise** (*jue*)—
The *Guangsheng Yi* says:
**Concise** (*jue*) is **simplification**.
Not exceeding two scrolls of text,
with over five thousand characters,
yet encompassing all dharmas (*wan fa bao luo*)—is this not concise?

Its text is **unobstructed** (*chang*)—
The *Guangsheng Yi* says:
**Unobstructed** (*chang*) means **clear and swift** (*tong kuai*).
The scripture says: *"My words are very easy to know, very easy to practice"*—is this not unobstructed?

Its words are **profound** (*ni*)—
The *Guangsheng Yi* says:
**Profound** (*ni*) means **near** (*jin*).
The scripture says: *"Observe the body with the body, observe the family with the family, and thus observe the world with the world"*—
and again: *"Without stepping outside, know the world; without peering through the window, see the Dao"*—is this not profound?

Those who wander in its **vestibules** (*lang*) and **ruins** (*fei*)—
believe they have ascended the hall and glimpsed its mysteries (*ao*).
The *Guangsheng Yi* says:
**Corridors** (*lang*) are the **walkways before the hall** (*ting qian*).
**Ruins** (*fei*) are the **vestibules beneath the hall** (*ting xia*).
**Mysteries** (*ao*) are the **inner chambers** (*shi zhi nei*), specifically the southwest corner.
It speaks of scholars and practitioners of the Dao,
who, upon first seeing this scripture,
believe they have exhausted principles (*li*) and nature (*xing*), reaching the utmost of profundity.
Yet when they delve deeply and ponder with earnest intent,
only then do they realize that in the finest tip (*qiuhao zhī duan*) of the Dao,
they have grasped but a fraction of its ten-thousandth part.

The *Guangsheng Yi* says:
*"To immerse oneself in study, to probe and investigate,
to exert one’s thoughts in seeking the Dao’s mysteries,
to exhaust the Dao’s sources,
to annotate and elucidate with the intent of capturing the sage’s meaning—
the more one seeks, the less the principle is understood,
and the deeper the sage’s intent becomes.*
**The tip of a hair** (*qiuhao*) is already minute.
And the **finest tip of a hair** (*qiuhao zhī duan*) is the most minute of all.
**Tip** (*duan*) means **end** (*mo*).
To say that at the **end of a hair’s tip** (*qiuhao zhī mo*)
one has not yet grasped a single part in ten-thousand—
this is the utmost of scarcity.

Thus, the **True Person of Azure Void** (*Bìxū Zhēnrén*) opens with this preface,
also saying: *Its essence lies in governing the body and the state*.
Yet only when they delve deeply and ponder with earnest intent
do they understand the Dao—
knowing its finest tip (*qiuhao zhī duan*), yet grasping but a fraction of its ten-thousandth part.

The **preface** says:
*"I now expound upon the two Daoist Classics of the *Morality* (*Dao De*) and *Great Mystery*,
all in accordance with the teachings passed down by my master,
the **True Person of Hong Meng Zhang Jun** (*Hongmēng Zhāng Zhēnrén*).
I have also compiled the subtle and essential elucidations
of past sages and practitioners who annotated this scripture,
ensuring their meanings align with the scripture’s intent.
If they are clearly attributed to their respective schools (*ben ren shi hao*),
one may take them as verification.
Moreover, I have examined the *Treasure House of Mysterious Dao* (*Xuan Du Bao Zang*),
the **Three Caverns and Four Aids** (*San Dong Si Fu*),
and all the scriptures, histories, and commentaries—
if any slightly accord with this scripture’s principles and meanings,
I have explored and recorded them as collateral evidence (*bang zheng*),
so that the **Great Dao’s profound truths** (*Lao Jun Da Dao Zhen Jing Chong Xuan zhi li*)
may be revealed with clarity,
and all future learners may enter through its gate with ease."*

From this, it is known that the **True Person of Azure Void** (*Bìxū Zhēnrén*)
both **proclaims the Dragon’s profound teachings** (*You Long Xuan Wei zhi jiao*)
and **opens the minds of future learners** (*kai fa hou xue meng mei zhi xin*).
Thus, the **Great Dao flourishes and spreads** (*fa lun chang zhuan*),
endless in its turning.

Is this not magnificent?

Moreover, he has compiled the **Four Commentaries** (*Si Zhu*) of the *Lingbao Scripture for Delivering People* (*Lingbao Du Ren Jing*)
and the *True Classic of Nan Hua* (*Nan Hua Zhen Jing*),
all stored in his **treasure chambers** (*cang shi*), yet transmitted to the world.
Observing his **sincerity in upholding the tradition and establishing teachings** (*fu zong li jiao zhi cheng*),
one can say: *This is the utmost.*

He also says: *"Its principles are like the dim and murky depths,
to be grasped by those who have attained enlightenment."*
This is a **word of humble self-effacement** (*qian xun zhi ci*).

chunks.original_text: 今太霞老人不揆管见，略将此开题本末疏之于前，如以萤爝之光，增益於太阳也。 其不知量也，断可识矣。 然亦未敢以此言为必当，庶几将来穷是经者，以此为门户而易入之也。 但请颖鉴之士，详择而已矣。 苟不以人废言，则为幸甚。 故曰太上道德经藏室，纂微开题疏也。 道德真经藏室纂微开题科文疏卷之五竟
chunks.translated_text:
「Now the *Tàixiá Lǎorén* does not measure himself by narrow views,
but briefly sets forth this *exegesis of the opening themes and conclusions* (*kāití běnmò shū*) beforehand—
like adding the glow of fireflies to the sun.

His **boundless ambition** (*qí bù yǐ liàng yě*)—
one can surely perceive it.

Yet he does not dare claim these words as absolute truth,
but hopes that future scholars who exhaustively study this *scripture* (*jīng*),
may take this as their **gateway** (*ménhù*) and find entry easier.

Only let those of **keen discernment** (*yǐngjiàn zhīshì*) carefully examine and select as they see fit.
If one does not reject these words because of their **human authorship** (*rén*), then it is most fortunate.

Thus, it is called:
*The *Dao De Jing* Treasure Chamber Exegesis—
A compilation of subtle elucidations and opening themes,*
*and the fifth scroll of the *Dao De Zhen Jing* Treasure Chamber Exegesis on the science of themes and texts.* (*Zhēn Jīng Cángshì Zuǎnwēi Kāití Kēwén Shū Juàn zhī wǔ jìng*)」
